PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 38 citizens) and Lajovic (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 35 citizens), Durack (from five citizens) and Lajovic ( from 345 citizens).

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

noting that, in 1967, an overwhelming majority of the people of Australia voted to amend the Constitution so that this Parliament would have the power to legislate for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to the people of any race for whom it was deemed necessary to make special laws;
noting also that the change to the Constitution was made to enable the national Parliament to discharge a national responsibility to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia; and
bearing in mind that the Senate unanimously adopted the following resolution on 20 February 1975:

'That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for the dispossession of their land':
(1) acknowledges that-

(a) the peoples whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of Australia and had occupied the territory of Australia for many thousands of years in accordance with an Aboriginal system of laws which determined the relationship of Aboriginal responsibility for and to the land to which they belonged;

(b) from the time of arrival of representatives of King George III of England, and the subsequent conquest of the land and the subjugation of the Aboriginal people, no settlement was concluded between those representatives and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(c) as a result of the colonization of the land by Great Britain the rights of the original owners and prior occupiers were totally disregarded;

(d) since the arrival of European settlers in Australia, the original inhabitants have been dispersed and dispossessed with the result that their descendants are, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society;

(e) this disadvantage persists, despite measures taken by State, Territory and Australian Governments, and by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves, so that further measures by Australian society as a whole, and by the Parliament of the Commonwealth in particular, will be required to ensure real equality and advancement for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; and
(2) considers, therefore, that the special measures which must be taken include action in the following main areas-

(a) The development of effective processes of consultation with Aboriginal people in order that the Aboriginal people may assert control of all aspects of their lives, having regard to the National Aboriginal Conference's responsibility to represent and present the views of Aboriginal and Islander people throughout Australia;
(b) the recognition by this Parliament of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's rights to land, in accordance with the following five basic principles:
(i) Aboriginal land to be held under inalienable freehold title;
(ii) protection of Aboriginal sites;
(iii) Aboriginal control in relation to mining on Aboriginal land;
(iv) access to mining royalty equivalents; and
(v) compensation for lost land to be negotiated;
(c) the continuation and acceleration of programs designed to ensure Aboriginal equality of opportunity in fields including health, education, housing, employment and welfare;
(d) the development of programs by all appropriate means to enable Aboriginal people to take part in economic activities for their own advantage;
(e) the promotion and protection of Aboriginal cultural identity, in ways considered appropriate by Aboriginals, including measures designed to:
(i) codify in writing Aboriginal languages, and assist in recording oral history;
(ii) preserve and protect Aboriginal sites and objects;
(iii) restore to Aboriginal people sacred objects relevant to their history, tradition and culture;
(iv) enhance the development of traditional or contemporary art forms; and
(v) provide interpreter services;
(f) restoration of the rights of Aboriginal families to raise and protect their own children by means of uniform laws and procedures in respect of child custody , fostering and adopting;
(g) respect for, and in appropriate circumstances, the application of, Aboriginal customary law and related practices as part of the law of Australia; and
(h) the development of improved community relations between Aboriginal and non- Aboriginal Australians, which requires a growing understanding on both sides by means of:
(i) public education programs; and
(ii) fostering the study of Aboriginal history, language, anthropology and archaeology in Australian schools and institutions of learning; and
(3) is therefore of the view that-

(a) the Australian people will be truly free and united only when the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation are free of the distress, the poverty and the alienation that has been their lot; and
(b) the Bicentennial year of 1988 provides an immediate focus point towards which all Australians can work together to achieve the objectives set out in this resolution.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, if one takes it from the last annual report, is to encourage Australia's export trade in goods and services by providing a specialised range of insurance guarantee and financing facilities not normally obtainable from the commercial market. It is worth remembering that the Corporation was first set up by a Liberal government to ensure that Australian exporters were not disadvantaged in terms of the facilities available to their overseas competitors. This obviously requires a change from time to time in the powers of the Corporation in response to changing international trading circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The first paragraph of the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) indicates that the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Amendment Bill proposes essentially technical amendments. However, as one reads further it becomes apparent that that is very much an understatement. In fact, the Government plans a very different charter for the Corporation. Most importantly, the Government has decided to remove the restrictions which generally limit EFIC services to those not normally available from the private sector. Thus in its export bank and insurance function it can be expected to compete with the private sector in future. Furthermore, as stated by the Minister, exporters will no longer be required to demonstrate a need to meet competition when seeking concessional export finance. Rather the EFIC, subject to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development undertakings, will take the initiative in determining appropriate credit terms. In other words , the Corporation will be able to give concessional finance to facilitiate developments of what are described in the Minister's speech as 'worthwhile trade development prospects'.

The Bill therefore raises all the difficult questions concerning the role of government and public money in trade development. The Government claims to have accepted a challenge to revitalise our export sector and clearly sees for itself an important role. Not only do we have this Bill but also we have in mind the Government's intentions in relation to an overseas trading corporation. Furthermore, the Government is placing an emphasis upon the export of manufactured goods, which raises the whole question of past policy and public funding being primarily orientated towards import protection in this sector rather than export development. Therefore, as I indicated at the commencement of my contribution, the Bill is important and raises important decisions.

The structural changes that have taken place in Australia's trade over the last decade are well known. Briefly I remind the Senate that the rural sector currently represents about 42 per cent of total exports compared with 80 per cent in the 1950s. This decline in the share of rural exports has in turn been matched by strong growth in exports of fuel and minerals which has accounted for the bulk of Australia's export growth in the last three decades. In 1980-81 fuel and mineral exports accounted for 40 per cent of Australia's exports, compared with less than one-tenth in the 1950s. Similarly in direction there has been a major change with a significant decline in the importance of the United Kingdom market and the diversification of exports to the expanding markets of the Western Pacific region and to the Middle East.

What is less well known is our relatively poor export performance. First, in both volume and value terms, Australia's trade performance has been below the annual average rate of growth for the world as a whole. Through the 1970s our share of total world trade fell from 1.69 per cent to 1.18 per cent. In fact, of the 33 largest exporters for which data is available, all but three achieved higher export growth rates than Australia. During the 1970s, Australia's international purchasing power increased by only 7.4 per cent. The increases for some countries broadly comparable to Australia were significantly greater: Canada, 66.3 per cent; New Zealand, 27.1 per cent; South Africa, 78.4 per cent; and Brazil, 128.5 per cent. Available International Monetary Fund data indicates that the only country to do worse than Australia during the 1970s in terms of improved purchasing power was Sri Lanka.

Secondly, although export markets have expanded in absolute terms, Australia has fallen back in its market share in many of its principal export markets. For example, Australian import penetration into Japan reached a peak of 9.39 per cent in 1972 but by 1979 it had declined to 5.69 per cent. Australian production as a percentage of all United States imports was 1.53 per cent in 1973, but by 1979 it had fallen back to 1.09 per cent. Over the same period, while Australian exports to China, Italy, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Saudi Arabia, Taiwan and the Association of South East Asian Nations have increased in both volume and value, market pene- tration has fallen. This dissappointing export performance appears to reflect Australia's declining standard of living relative to that of many of our trading partners. Given our small domestic market, an improved export performance would appear to be obviously critical in reversing that trend.

A number of reasons for our poor trade performance appear obvious. First, the relatively high concentration of exports in primary products. Not only have Australian primary products been one of the slowest growth sectors in world trade over recent years, they have also been concentrated in slow growth areas of North America and Europe. Agricultural trade has, of course, been subject to extensive trade barriers and export subsidies most evident in the common agricultural policy of the European Economic Community countries. Secondly, Australia has not been able to compete with the industrialised nations of South East and East Asia in ensuring exports markets in manufactured commodities. Australia's industrial policy has remained of the same character over the last 30 years, as I said, essentially one of import replacement rather than export orientated. The result has been the development of a broadly based manufacturing sector which, while initially import competitive, has been increasingly unable to withstand import competition. Thirdly, we have seen a declining competitiveness of the Australian trade sector with high domestic labour costs, prohibitive transport costs, and at times poor exchange rate management and inappropriate taxation policies.

Australia retains a high ranking in primary and extractive commodities because of an obvious competitive advantage. That competitive advantage can be undermined by inappropriate policies such as high tariffs on imported plant and equipment and uncompetitive shipping rates. However, a further comparative advantage we have is our location in the Asian-Pacific region. We are located in the most rapidly growing, economically speaking, region of the world and a region of dynamic economies based on outward looking trade orientated industrialisation strategies. We have a clear contrast with some western European economies which have stagnated. Projections of their future have been dominated by a preoccupation with policy directed at the stabilisation of incomes and economic structures, which has resulted in slower gross domestic product growth.

Australia's approach to its economy has been of the industrialised West European mould, and with a similar result. Our reaction to the economic dynamism of our region has been one of despair rather than recognition of the tremendous trade opportunities which that gives us. High growth rates and trade orientated development strategies within our region are expected to continue. By the end of this century, the Asian Pacific region will encompass an immense economy, certainly, far from fully integrated but with high degrees of interdependence in many spheres. Market opportunities for Australia will be great, but it will require different attitudes if we are not only to protect our natural competitive advances in relation to primary products but also to maximise the opportunities presented by this regional economic growth. It will be the manufacturing sector which will face the greatest challenge. Peter Vidler of the economics and commerce group of our Parliamentary Library, in a recent paper, said:

While there will continue to be a demand for Australian mineral resources from Asia, the challenge arising from the growth of Asian countries lies in the implications for manufacturing industry. As countries such as Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong move to more advanced stages of development, their import demand will also change from predominately natural resources, to include semi processed material and items of capital equipment. Australia's economic opportunities will be maximised if it can reorient its manufacturing sector away from its domestic market orientation to meet this new demand.

It is obvious that the traditional labour intensive Australian manufacturing sector will be incapable of sustaining any significant competitive presence. It must shift away from its concentration on high labour input and low value-added production towards more capital intensive high value-added products, which can find market niches in the expanding Asian economies. We must build on the comparative advantages of our resource and energy endowments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about work? What about employment?

—That is right, but the question is whether one can create employment by continuing with the policies of the past or whether one has to look in a new direction. I am suggesting that a new direction will be essential. I am saying that we must not disregard the comparative advantages which we have; we must build upon them. Those comparative advantages, obviously, are resource and energy endowments, and to date a relatively well-educated work force. Technology intensive industrial activities offer major opportunities for generating more wealth and increased employment. In the key technology areas, particularly in the fields of electronic technology, communication technology, biotechnology, computer software, lasers for medical technology, to name only a few, opportunities abound. I remind Senator Harradine that we have shown that we can build on our comparative advantages in computer control, mining processes and high technology dry land farming techniques. We may not be able to compete in the manufacture of microchips, but we can compete in the development possibilities spawned by the new technology. These are new, different goods, systems and services which would be not only import competitive but also export seeking. The report of the panel which reviewed the Australian Trade Commissioner Service was released only a few weeks ago and stated in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Product and market opportunities in some traditional areas are declining while new opportunities, for example in skills and services, are emerging. Other nations are already responding to these world developments and Australia needs to move quickly if it is to take advantage of new product and market opportunities.

The panel reminded us that such changes are most graphically evident in our major trading partner, Japan. Traditional Australian exports face static or declining markets in Japan. Yet changing industry structures and consumption patterns are creating substantial new and rapidly growing markets in a segment of the Japanese market that Australia has barely broached. To retain Australia's trading status in Japan and generate employment in Australia we must find a way into the growing segments of the Japanese import market, and this will require a more substantial and imaginative commitment to the market than has been mounted to date. For Australia to meet this challenge it will require outward-looking entrepreneurs, a dedicated work force, the production of high quality, imaginitive-

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got a dedicated work force already.
—If Senator Harradine does not think a dedicated work force will be necessary, I am surprised.
—I do. We have got it already.
—We will need the production of quality, imaginative, yet practical products and aggressive export marketing.
—You should apply the Standing Orders. You will always get trouble when senators read their speeches.

—Mr President, I know some people think it would be better if we spent all day debating the Sex Discrimination Bill. There are some in this chamber who think there are other subjects that are at least as important. However, this will require the right policies from government. These will include not only the right macro-economic policies affecting the competitiveness of Australia's exports, for example exchange rate, fiscal and monetary policy, but also specific policies, for example export credit to which this Bill relates and export market development grants, which we debated last year. The panel identified a number of specific areas in which government policy can make a positive contribution to an improved trade performance. The first area related to offsets. The panel mentioned the fact that offset opportunities amounting to some $1.5 billion are currently outstanding against existing contracts.
—Can't you incorporate it?
—I know that some honourable senators are in a hurry to get home. They have all day to debate four Bills, one of which has already been dealt with .
—Stop reading your speech and give it to us from the heart.

—It would take longer if I did that. I was about to refer to a number of specific suggested areas in which government policy can make a positive contribution to an improved trade performance. The first I mentioned related to offsets. I reminded the Senate that offset opportunities amounting to some $1.5 billion are currently outstanding against existing contracts at a time of underemployment in the Australian economy. I should have thought that that would be of particular interest to the Senate. The panel supports a greater focus of attention being placed on non-defence offsets and a correspondingly closer role for the Minister for Trade in the development and implementation of the offsets program.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the panel believed that greater emphasis should be placed on the utilisation of Australian goods and services in support of the Australian aid program. Thirdly, the panel noted the value of government purchasing and the promotion of industries with export potential, particularly in areas such as high technology and consultancy contracting. Fourthly, the panel noted the number of companies in Australia-some 900-which are subject to export franchise restrictions covering some 5,400 exportable profit areas and suggested that perhaps a policy of incentives should be provided to encourage multinationals to liberalise franchise restrictions. I should have thought that that would be particularly important to those on the other side. Fifthly, the panel felt that greater emphasis should be given to Australian investment overseas which would allow the investor to take advantage of expected growth in the host country market, overcome tariffs and other import barriers and gain access to markets adjacent to the host country. Sixthly, the panel raised the problem of State- Commonwealth relations and stated:

The competition among States in areas of promotion of exports, state government purchasing and offsets programs is costly, has resulted in fragmentation of industry development in Australia and has created confusion in the minds of overseas governments and business as to the respective roles of the Commonwealth and States in external trade.

Seventhly, the panel raised the interesting subject of the marketing of public sector skills. It said that in areas such as health, education, power generation , and agriculture there are skills and expertise within Australia which have the potential to be marketed overseas. These are the different directions for which I presume Senator Harradine was searching. However, what comes out most clearly from the report is the lack of a long term, external commercial strategy for Australia, a lesson that should be learned from the Government-determined goals of Japan. I gather from the agitation in the chamber that the Senate is very anxious to proceed with the Sex Discrimination Bill. If I might return to the Bill before us and the expanded role that it gives the Government in relation to trade credit, the Minister used a number of times, in his second reading speech, the word 'aggressive'. I think there is a need for Australia to become more aggressive in its export performance. For too long we have followed rather than led. Therefore, I support the extension of favourable credit terms to allow new market opportunities to be seized, rather than simply to combat the competition of others.

With regard to the extension of services that may be otherwise obtainable from the commercial market, I remind the Senate that the support of the Campbell Committee for the Corporation seems to be based largely on the fact that it fills what is at present a market gap. For the Corporation to go further and duplicate services that are offered by the commercial sector would appear to offer nothing further, or better, than currently exists. There are sufficient challenges for the Government in the area of trade development without duplicating what already exists. However, in general I welcome the updating of the Corporation, the recognition by the Government of the importance of an export manufacturing sector and the contribution that it claims to be willing to make towards more aggressive marketing. I trust that it will give further attention to the deficiencies identified by the panel to review the Australian Trade Commissioner Service, and recognise the urgent need for an export policy that is based on the challenges of the future, not of the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Life Insurance Amendment Bill and the Insurance Amendment Bill. The Opposition supports each of these Bills. Because of the pressures of time I will restrict my comments to the Insurance Amendment Bill. The main features of that Bill are designed to strengthen the financial standards imposed on general non-life insurance companies. These strengthening provisions are aimed at two principal areas-to increase the paid-up capital and solvency requirements. The motivating forces which have caused the Government at last to act in this area are the recent collapses in the insurance industry of companies such as Palmdale Insurance Ltd and Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Ltd, in addition to a number of collapses of brokering firms.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years a number of people have recognised that the crux of the problem in the insurance industry can be sheeted home to two principal areas. Firstly, both the Insurance Act and the Insurance Commissioner have been toothless tigers . In addition to that, there has been no attempt to control brokerage operations within the industry. The main thrust of the Insurance Commissioner's reports on the general insurance industry in recent years has been directed towards the failure, firstly, to lodge returns on time. In certain circumstances when some of the returns are received by the Commissioner there has also been the question of the ability of the Commissioner's Office to interpret the financial thrust of some companies. Remedial action has therefore been required in this area. The same problem arose in the United Kingdom with the Board of Trade having a similar problem. One can cast one's mind back several years to the collapse of Vehicle and General in the United Kingdom. The problem was predominantly not located until it was too late. There appear to be similar sorts of difficulties in Australia.

But unlike the banking industry, where the Federal Government determines what overseas banks can operate in Australia, over the last decade insurance interests from overseas have entered the market in Australia with certain detrimental effects upon the whole industry. The advent some decades ago of overseas insurance in the Australian market was the signal for a price-cutting war, the responsibility for which must largely be accepted by the insurance brokers of Australia playing one insurance company off against another and eventually finding the weak reeds within the industry. At last the Federal Government, in its attempt to stabilise the insurance industry for the benefit of the consumers, has decided to act. The amendments in clause 16 of the Insurance Amendment Bill provide some limitations on what is deemed to be proper to include as assets, for example, a limit on outstanding premiums. Clause 16 places some limitations on the extent to which outstanding premiums can be brought into account as assets. Proper registration of brokers with the insurance industry in Australia would go a long way towards returning stability to the industry.

I welcome the introduction of a Bill, perhaps in the autumn session of Parliament, to fulfill this need. All brokers should be registered and the condition of their registration should be such that it would bring about a stability which would ensure a better result for the industry generally. Historically one of the weaknesses within the insurance industry is the granting of credit. This problem is highlighted particularly with major companies whose insurance program is handled by brokers. It is a commonly accepted fact that the due date is reached before negotiations take place with the insurer. This means, in effect, that they are buying time. There is probably a period of negotiation of two, three, four months or even longer before the final terms and conditions are agreed upon for the policy year. The result of this is that the broker does not receive premiums, nor are they passed on to the company, for up to six to nine months. This must be a disability for the insurance industry generally.

No one would deny that the law of insurance requires clarification. It is also clear that with rapidly changing technology, not only in industry but also in commerce, the insurance industry has been under great stress to keep pace with these changes. But it is not enough on its own to clarify the law of insurance, to clear up issues regarding policy wording and contracts for the benefit of the consumer. It goes much deeper than that. The whole financial structure of the industry must also be streamlined in order that people's interests are protected at all times and that company collapses can be minimised. The main concern of the insurance industry should be financial stability so that the client is protected at all times and is not faced with the prospect of his policy being worthless. It may well be that, apart from the annual returns that are submitted by companies to the Commissioner, there should be some form of quarterly return. I welcome the improvements that are in this Bill. I, on behalf of the Opposition , support both of these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee was last dealing with clauses 5 and 6 of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2) Senator Ryan gave me a set of words relating to the period an employee should be available to fulfil the responsibilities of the job. The question I was asking, because I think it is relevant and will be of a great deal of interest to many employers, is this: Is it an offence for an employer, in his or her naivete, to ask an employee whether she is married and whether she is planning to have a family in the immediate future? The question is being asked because the position is such that it would require considerable training for the employer to receive any benefit, reward or return for the investment in the employee, and an employer would require an employee to spend considerable time in the position. The question is: Is it an offence to ask either of these questions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -It would be an offence to refuse a person employment or promotion in employment on the ground of marital status or pregnancy. It would not be an offence for an employer to seek information concerning an employee's availability, which may include information about that person's marital status or many other things. It would not be an offence to ask any questions. It would not be an offence to refuse an employee a job on the ground that he or she will be unavailable for any reason to fulfil the terms of the employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —To refresh the memory of the Committee, the provisions of clauses 5 and 6 outlaw discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status. The amendment that has been moved by the Opposition is to incorporate the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'. I draw the attention of the Committee to the comments that were made by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) on Tuesday evening when we were last discussing this matter. The Minister, in her responses to the questions that were asked, used the word 'reasonable'. Quite clearly, that is the only way that these measures can be truly anti-discrimination measures; in other words, to ensure that these measures are not used for ulterior purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The example I gave of the possible operation of clause 6, which deals with discrimination on the ground of marital status, has not been properly answered by the Minister. Because the definition of martial status includes the de facto spouse of another person, and because that then in turn places marital status, for the purpose of this clause, at the same level and on the same status as a bona fide marriage relationship, it creates and will create problems. As I indicated on the previous occasion, the United Nations Convention was not intended to do that. It was not intended to palce a de facto relationship on the same basis as a bona fide marriage relationship.

I draw the Committee's attention again to the possible effect of this clause on , for example, an owner of a hotel in a country town in which there may be two hotels. In a number of towns I know, there are more hotels than residences; but I just take as an example the more typical country town, perhaps, in which there are two hotels. Those hotels are the centre for the social life of the community . Let us say, for example, that the hotel-keeper wanted to go away and wanted to ensure that his hotel was properly cared for and was properly run as the social centre of the town and that he gave the hotel charge to a manager. Let us suppose that the manager is a married man in the town and that whilst the hotel- keeper is away, he shacks up with a barmaid. Under this measure, the hotel- keeper cannot, in those circumstances and for that reason, sack the manager.

TALK.START.PARA: —The licensing authority would, though.
—No; the licensing authority cannot, under this measure.
—The licensing authority has a right over what happens in that hotel.

—Oh no. The licensing authority, under this measure, is covered by this measure. That is the point. The Crown is bound. In those circumstances, the hotel-keeper, under this measure, would not be able to sack the manager. The licensing authority could do nothing about it, and the hotel- keeper would lose his business because all the locals would go down to Jack Ryan 's to engage in their social life there. Surely this is not a matter with which this Bill was designed to interfere; not with those sorts of rights and responsibilities. That is one of the reasons why I sought to have deleted from the definition of 'marital status' the aspect of a de facto spouse. Unfortunately, I received no support from the Opposition, the Liberal Party or the National Party.
—You did not get any from me, unless you meant to include me in the Opposition.

—No, I certainly did not get any support from Senator Haines or the Australian Democrats. I did not expect it. But these are the aspects of the measure that have not been fully considered. When I was attempting to explain the situation, I am afraid that the Committee was discussing matters individually with other people and not a great deal of attention was being paid to the matters that were raised at that particular stage. In particular I refer to the matter that I alone can raise in this chamber because I was the only one from this chamber who was present-that is, the matter relating to the development of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women and the drafts of the United Nations Convention. No mention was made of de facto spouse being given the same status as married spouse under the marital status provisions of the United Nations Convention. I again raise that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: To retrieve the situation somewhat, it is necessary to support the Opposition's amendment. I do support the Opposition's amendment. To retrieve it further, it will be necessary subsequently, although it will not overcome the whole problem because of the matters that have just been raised, to place in a conscientious objection clause not specifically for the de facto situation but, more importantly, for greater and graver issues that will arise as a result of this legislation. I support the proposal by the Opposition to add at the appropriate parts of clauses 5 and 6 the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for his support of our amendment. I also thank him for reminding the Committee of the points he was making at the end of the debate on Tuesday night. I respond to the statement of Senator Harradine when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I believe that the Opposition's amendment is probably adequate, I would have picked up what the Minister said and used the words 'reasonably relevant in the circumstances' rather than 'reasonable in the circumstances'.

I say two things: First of all, I think the phrase 'reasonable in the circumstances' carries with it relevance. If we are talking about a particular situation, we are talking about whether something is relevant. However, if the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) were to indicate that she would prefer the amendment to read 'reasonably relevant in the circumstances' and the Government were to accept that amendment, I would be quite happy to change our amendment to that wording. I want to make one other point. I made some reference on Tuesday night to clause 30 (2). The Minister in debate pointed out that clause 30 (2) reads:

Without limiting the generality of sub-section (1), it is a genuine occupational qualification, in relation to a particular position, to be a person of a particular sex (in this sub-section referred to as the ''relevant sex'' if- . . .

(h) the position is declared, by regulations made for the purposes of this paragraph, to be a position in relation to which it is a genuine occupational qualification to be a person of a particular sex.

This follows a number of paragraphs which are exemptions in a sense to this section on prohibiting discrimination on the grounds of sex and to which we seek to add the words 'reasonable in the circumstances'. I indicate to the Government that, whilst paragraph (h) of clause 30 (2) may well pick up a number of the sorts of things that people have in their minds when they are attracted to our amendment, it is not desirable in my opinion for these things to be done by government regulation. It would be better to give the Commissioner the right to make that judgment in individual cases. The Commission will become very experienced in the matter and I am sure that it will embark on the implementation of this Bill in the way it is meant to be implemented. But I am also sure that there will be some cases that come to it, which will be difficult for it, where a fairer and more acceptable decision could be made on the matters of sex discrimination and marital status if the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances' were there and the Commission did not have to rely on perhaps making some report to government about some regulation that may need to be made in a certain situation that has been overlooked in paragraphs (a) to (g). Of course, in the meantime, even if the Government accepted that and regulated accordingly, the Commission would have had to rule against someone, even though its ruling may be not entirely reasonable. I reiterate that the Opposition is not attempting to water down the Bill. It is trying to make the Bill more acceptable and fairer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is 'That the words proposed to be added to clauses 5 and 6 by Senator Martin's amendments Nos. (1) and (2) be added'. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no.
— Mr Chairman, is not the Minister going to say whether the scenario that I put forward is covered by this proposition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is very well aware that he raised that example the other night. I answered that example the other night. I have also indicated to the Opposition that we believe that its amendments are begging the question of what discrimination is, whether it is reasonable to treat people differently under particular circumstances. We have made exemptions or indicated that further exemptions can be made. Therefore, the Opposition's amendments are not acceptable. The question of the rights of employers who are running businesses to treat people differently on the grounds of their marital status has been dealt with by my remarks the other day. Senator Harradine simply repeated the point he made the other night. I repeat that his views are not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow amendments that will clarify the amendment I will move in a moment.
—What are you doing?

—The first amendment which I will put forward will not clarify the intention of what I am attempting to do; so I thought I would foreshadow two further amendments to clause 40 (1). I am simply refining the definition of marital status because the most obvious discrimination against non-working spouses is in the income tax laws. If a spouse is considered dependent then, according to the Australian Taxation Office, she is not entitled to any of her husband's income. This is commonly called splitting of incomes. That will clarify the situation for Senator Georges. I believe that a husband and wife are a partnership. It is only through the work of the wife in the home and the fact that she does run the home and look after the children that the husband is able to earn the income that he does. I believe that the Australian Taxation Office discriminates against the non-working spouse.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give some figures, though I do want to be brief. The husband of a couple earning half the average weekly income-$8,899, which is a very small income-pays $395 in tax each year. That is a gross injustice. I believe that if he has a dependent spouse he is able to earn his income only because she does as much as she does for him. They are in partnership. They should be able, if they so choose, to split their income. If that were permissible and if the wife were not discriminated against in that situation that family would not be paying tax at all. I do not believe that a couple on that sort of income, particularly if they have children, should pay tax at all. If the average weekly wage of $17,000 is earned the husband pays a considerable amount of tax, totalling $3,121. If the splitting of income were allowed the husband would pay $1,358, the wife would pay the same and there would be a saving of $405 in the tax bill for that family . For Senator Georges's information I am suggesting that if the wife is at home, looking after dependent children and doing normal household chores, if her life is one of supporting her husband, she is in effect in partnership with her husband and should be entitled to the tax free area that other people are entitled to. We discriminate against her by not allowing her that tax benefit.

I am suggesting that the Bill ought to fix that discrimination, and I will attempt to do this with my additional clause 6(3). Later I will move other amendments to rectify the injustice whereby non-earning spouses are discriminated against. If the Government believes that this Bill will create justice and do away with discrimination in all areas except, as it has already said, the social welfare area-of course the taxation area has not been mentioned -I believe that we must, in all justice, go the whole way.

I do not intend to speak any further on that, Mr Chairman. I hope that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) can explain the Government's position to me. I now move:
(1) Page 7, after sub-clause 6 (2), add the following sub-clause:

''(3) Where a person who is married and who is not engaged in remunerated employment is, by reason of those conditions, treated less favourably, in circumstances that are the same or are not materially different, than another person to whom either of those conditions does not apply, that first-mentioned person shall be taken to have been discriminated against on the ground of the martial status of that first-mentioned person.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to say that the Opposition will not support Senator Walters's amendment. We do not believe that the amendment is appropriate to this Bill.
—It goes beyond the scope of the Bill.

—As Senator Missen indicates, it really does go beyond the scope of this Bill. It is something that ought to be looked at for example in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Act which is mentioned in the subsequent amendment. For that reason we will not support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept Senator Walters's amendment for the same reasons that Senator Martin has just explained as to why the amendment is unacceptable to the Opposition. It is well beyond the scope of this Bill to start to make changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Government has the matter of taxation under review through the operation of the Economic Planning Advisory Council and Senator Walters is welcome to put to that body her views about desirable changes in taxation arrangements. It is totally inappropriate to attempt to bring the operation of the taxation Act into the scope of this Bill. So the amendment is not acceptable.

— What the Minister has said is not substantiated by the fact that the Bill already specifically excludes the Department of Social Security. It does not exclude the Australian Taxation Office; it only excludes the Department of Social Security. If the Government says that it is beyond the capacity of this Bill to apply it to other departments, there would have been no need for the Government to have made the exclusions that it has made. The fact that it has excluded the Department of Social Security indicates very clearly that other departments are not excluded. Indeed, there is a direction that the Commonwealth departments are to abide by this Bill. It is not outside the scope of this Bill; it is very clearly within the scope of this Bill. I would like to hear the Minister's comment on that, because she has given an indication throughout the debate on this Bill that Government departments must abide by it. She is very concerned that Commonwealth departments should abide by the sex discrimination, marital and pregnancy clauses. Just because she is not particularly keen on my amendment, she says: ' It is outside the scope of the Bill'. It is not an excluded department, as is the Department of Social Security, and it is therefore within the scope of this Bill.
—No. I briefly say that, unfortunately, Senator Walters has not come to a logical conclusion with regard to her argument.
—She has moved an amendment and spoken twice. Is not the debate closed?

—If I may interrupt Senator Georges, it is one thing to accept the fact that under the Bill certain departments are excluded. It does not go on to change the law in respect of those departments by saying that the Department of Social Security will do various other things. But in this case the amendment would create a new provision in the income tax law. I put it that not only does it not follow that because we exclude some departments we can do what we like about any other departments and change the tax law in a Bill such as this, but also this is a Bill which, by its long title and other provisions, concerns the matter of discrimination. It does not change the tax laws of the Commonwealth. So far as the amendment is concerned, however sound the idea might be, I suggest it is beyond the scope of the Bill and is therefore out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to support the amendment and I do so after an examination of the provisions of the Bill. Article 1 of the Bill's Schedule states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of the present Convention, the term 'discrimination against women' shall mean any distinction, exclusion or restriction made on the basis of sex which has the effect or purpose of impairing or nullifying the recognition, enjoyment or exercise by women, irrespective of their marital status, on a basis of equality of men and women, of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the political, economic, social, cultural, civil or any other field.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is the Convention--
—Yes, that is the Convention.
—It is not part of the Bill; it is in the Schedule.
—I am being enlightened here. Senator Missen says that it is not part of the Bill. I am reading from the Schedule to the Bill.
—The Bill does not implement all of the Convention; it implements only part of it.
—Yes. I wish the Minister would further enlighten us on some of these matters, which she has not done so far. The objects of the Bill are:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to give effect to certain provisions of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; to eliminate, so far as is possible, discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of work, accommodation, education, provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land, the activities of clubs, and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs . . .

I am the first to admit-the Minister has recognised and stated this-that the Bill does not attempt to implement all of the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. But let us take the case of people who work. The people about whom Senator Walters is speaking are not parasites, they are workers. This Bill binds the Crown. It binds the Australian Taxation Office. It is a recognition, as it were, of the work that is done in the home that ought to be raised in the consciousness of the Parliament at this time-it is appropriate to do so-and it is for the Parliament to express its view as to how this legislation ought to operate. There are many ways in which proper recognition can be given to the women at home who are doing the most important job that a mother can do, and that is raising the family. Frankly it is appropriate that this matter be raised here. If this legislation goes through I am not too sure what effect it would have on the Taxation Office or whether we would perhaps be imposing a burden which we cannot impose under clause 57. Presumably the mover of the motion has checked out all of those matters. Nevertheless, if there is some problem in that regard obviously it can be sorted out between now and next February or March or whenever the House of Representatives pursues this matter.

I am happy that Senator Walters has raised this matter. There are additional ways in which mothers, who are doing this most important job, can be recognised in the financial sense, such as a homemaker's allowance, split incomes and a number of other ways. But at present it should be recognised that they are, as Senator Walters said, discriminated against. I congratulate her for raising the matter in the form that she has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters moved an amendment, admittedly within the Committee stage. Having moved the amendment the matter is therefore open to discussion, but then Senator Walters spoke a second time. I take it that at that second time she was in reply and therefore closed the debate.
—Come on, George.

—Wait a moment. If it is not correct it ought to be correct. All I am saying to honourable senators is that when we are in the Committee stage the movement of an amendment or a motion comes within the scope of the Standing Orders that apply. If we do not follow the Standing Orders we will get into terrible difficulties here because we are debating an amendment to which Senator Walters has responded. Normally that would have closed the debate but we have a series of other speeches now.

—Senator Georges, according to standing order 407 honourable senators may speak as many times as they choose during the Committee stage. A reply by someone who has moved an amendment does not close that debate, because that would precisely counteract standing order 407.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I can assure Senator Georges that I am not going to make a long speech. I only want to say a few words in support of Senator Walters's amendment. Whether my remarks are appropriate or not remains to be seen. Nevertheless the aim of this Bill is to eliminate discrimination against women.
—Take it up under the tax laws.
—I would like to. I have taken it up previously in debate. I must admit that nobody to this point has agreed with my suggestion that splitting incomes would help families. I am sure it would.
—I agree with you.

—Thank you, Senator Harradine. I feel that the present tax laws discriminate against women who stay at home. If this Bill eliminates discrimination against women, I certainly feel that Senator Walters's amendment is a very good one. In fact, in my speech during the second reading debate I suggested that each partner of a two-income family should be allowed to earn $4, 000 tax free each year. That means that a two-income family would receive $8,000 tax free each year. I think that with the very small spouse rebate that is now being paid and with costs they are these days, it is really no wonder that married women feel they have to go out to work. I think that the woman who stays at home to rear a family certainly works very hard. I am glad that Senator Walters has decided to move her amendment. I have much pleasure in supporting it .

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 7 and 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 11-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 8, sub-clause 9 (10), lines 32 to 35 leave out the sub-clause.
(4) Page 10, clause 9, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clause:
''(21) The prescribed provisions of Part II shall not have effect except as aforesaid and shall not otherwise rely upon the Convention for their effect and application.''.
(5) Page 10, sub-clause 10 (1), lines 8 to 10, leave out the sub-clause.
(6) Page 10, sub-clause 11 (1), lines 35 and 36, leave out the sub-clause.

These four Opposition amendments all relate to the same issue; that is, the very highly controversial use of the external affairs power in the Sex Discrimination Bill. We debated at some length the use of this power in a Bill which related to South West Tasmania. We discussed the rights and wrongs of the Commonwealth extending its power into areas which have traditionally been the responsibilities of State governments through the use of the external affairs power. Since that debate the High Court of Australia has ruled by a majority decision of four to three that the Commonwealth was entitled to use that power. I said in my speech on the Sex Discrimination Bill at the second reading stage that I was dismayed, altogether not surprised, by the judgment of the High Court for a number of reasons. I feared that the Government would not be able to resist the temptation to proceed with the Sex Discrimination Bill with a reliance on that power. I also feared that those who really just did not want any legislation outlawing discrimination on the grounds of sex in this country would use that use of the external affairs power as a stick with which to beat this Bill.

The Opposition has said freely that there are a lot of good things in the Bill. However, we believe some improvements can be made. The legislative powers of the Commonwealth are already quite extensive in the areas that the Bill covers. They are outlined in clause 9. They are very numerous. The application of the external affairs power is in itself deficient. Because it depends on the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women it gives the Commonwealth the power, if it seeks to use it, only in matters which relate to discrimination against women. It does not extend to discrimination against men, which is a deficiency. One of the strengths of the Bill is that it is a Bill to outlaw discrimination on the basis of sex, whether it be discrimination against men or women. The fact, as it will emerge, that some parts of the Bill are limited because they apply only to women will, I think, affect public acceptance of the Bill. The very use of the external affairs power will certainly affect acceptance of the Bill.

The Opposition supported ratification of the Convention. It was our policy when in government to ratify and there were many statements on the record at the end of last year that the Government expected to ratify early this year. An election intervened and, as it happened, it was the Hawke Government, not the Fraser Government, which was in power when the Convention was ratified. We support the Convention and its ratification but we do not think it should be used in this way. We took this view in government but that in no way took away from our support for the principles of the Convention and our intention to implement the relevant areas in Australia. Also, we were aware when in government that a government could try to avail itself of the external affairs power in a number of ways, so it has long since been known that the potential was there. It was not until a government actually legislated and was tempted, as the Hawke Government was tempted in relation to South West Tasmania, and the matter was tested in the High Court of Australia that the issue was settled. It was not settled as clearly as some people seem to think. Some people think that because the High Court upheld the use of the external affairs power in the case of the Tasmanian dam, the Commonwealth Government can sign any international treaty and then take whatever powers it might assume flows from that. The actual decision was a little more complex than that. Nevertheless, it symbolised the transferring of a lot of power. The fact that the decision was as close as it was shows that it is an area of some disputation and doubt. That is a position of which we were aware when in Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are questioning the High Court decision.
—I am not. Will Senator Georges please be quiet. He has not made any worthwhile contribution to this debate. In a few minutes I expect he will be complaining about people wasting time.
—You thought of it first.
—I ask Senator Martin not to reply to interjections. She has the call.

—I would rather that sort of interjection were not made, Mr Chairman, with respect. The Fraser Government was well aware of the potential to use the external affairs power although it was not absolutely certain which way the High Court would rule. I expect that would depend on the circumstances of the case. In the case of South West Tasmania, the external affairs power was not the only power the Commonwealth relied on. It was a linkage of that power with other powers and other factors which led to the upholding of the legislation. The effect of our amendments will be to take out whatever reliance there is on the external affairs power. Nonetheless, there would be wide ranging powers for the Commonwealth to legislate. There would be areas in which it could go which some people might find obnoxious, but the Commonwealth would have that power without doubt. I think that it would also take away some of the fears and objections to the Bill which now centre on the Convention. We do not object to the Convention being in the Schedule and we will not oppose it, but there clearly is a potential for extension of this Bill through decisions of one kind or another. Senator Harradine pointed out those potentials in his speech during the second reading debate. That would be to the deteriment of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I think that with a Bill like this, one is touching on some pretty basic feelings and attitudes in the community. The second reading debate illustrated that by the number of people who felt that they ought to speak and put their views on the record although they might have been reiterating views that had already been expressed. They were not speaking just for the purpose of expressing a point of view but because they thought it necessary to express their point of view. This is fairly typical of debate on Bills which are of a basic social nature. This Bill is of that nature. It will affect quite a few people. It is social in that it will affect people's attitudes towards other people, attitudes which may be based on their sex, marital status or state of pregnancy. As such, it is a Bill that will take a little acceptance as did, for example, the Family Law Act when it was passed. That was an Act that I supported at the time.

So I say to the Government that I move these amendments with the best intentions. I hope this Bill will be accepted and that in its implementation those who now fear it will see that they did not have so much to fear. There is, as the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) would be well aware, very strong passions on the subject of the use of the external affairs powers on behalf of certain State governments. It is not necessary to use the power. The non-use of the powers would diminish the Bill very little, but I think that it would enhance the acceptance of the Bill very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I support this measure. I do not intend to canvass what I said in the second reading debate. I believe that the Government is and will be in difficulties in regard to this provision, but it is the decision of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and, frankly, the Minister may have to live with it. When I raised, in the Committee stage, the matter of the definition of 'marital status' she indicated that whilst I might be right in my views on the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, there was no intention on the part of the proposers of the Convention to include 'de facto spouse' as part of the definition of marital status and that the Parliament had power under the marriage power of the Constitution. It would be very odd indeed if that power were relied upon to place de facto relationships on the same level as a bona fide married relationship. For the information of the Committee I will read the comments that were made by the Department of Foreign Affairs when this matter was being discussed in the United Nations General Assembly committees and in the working party. In the supplementary brief of the Department of Foreign Affairs, UNGA 32/Item 85, entitled 'Draft Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women', the Department said:

SPEECH.PARA: The major difficulty, for Australia and perhaps for other states which are federations of one sort or another, is that many articles of the Convention require legislative guarantees of women's rights in areas of law which are the responsibility of the states.

I ask the Committee to consider that very carefully. It says that those who negotiated on behalf of Australia the draft of the United Nations Convention on which this Bill is based were told that the legislative guarantees were in areas of law which are the responsibilities of the States. Of course, that was before the Koowarta decision and the Tasmanian dams decision. The whole ball game has changed. I remember quite clearly, when I raised in New York some of the problems that I am or will be raising here, that I was told: 'Don't bother about that, Senator. The States will knock that off'. Of course, those who were negotiating that treaty believed that was the situation. The nature of negotiations that take place at this level is such that, in the words used to me : 'You can give way on certain things knowing full well that they will be knocked off in the States'. That was the understanding of the constitutional situation at the time. I think members of Parliament would also have had that understanding of the Constitution. They would understand that we did not have the power in many of the areas in which we say we have it now. We did not have the power to impose the view of the Commonwealth Parliament on the parliaments of the States by invoking international treaties of this character. Clearly, the Department of Foreign Affairs did not have that power, because this is its document. I will read it again and leave the matter at that:

The major difficulty, for Australia and perhaps for other states which are federations of one sort or another, is that many articles of the Convention require legislative guarantees of women's rights in areas of law which are the responsibility of the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition has relatively few amendments left to move and I believe that the one before the Committee now is the most important of them. It strikes at the very basis of our Constitution.
—I didn't regard it as the most important amendment to come, though.

—I believe that this has other connotations apart from the Sex Discrimination Bill. That is why I believe it is so important. I believe the Government has secured this power under false pretences. It has altered the Constitution by a backdoor method. The Constitution should rightly have been altered by the people of Australia. It was not altered by the people of Australia; it was altered by the Hawke Government in trying to take over the rights of one of the small States. That State, of course, is Tasmania, which challenged the Government through the High Court of Australia. As has already been said, I think by Senator Martin, the fact that the margin in that judgment was so close points out more clearly than anything I could say that the alteration of the Constitution in such a major way has relied on the opinion of seven men, not on the opinion of the Australian people.

—I am not reflecting on the Court. The Court was put in an invidious position, one in which it should never have been put. It should never have been asked to alter the Constitution in such a major way. The judges were forced to come up with a decision. —You are questioning the integrity of the Court.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. You ought not to allow Senator Walters to question the integrity of the judges. If the Opposition is going to waste time, in its determination to go all day, I may as well raise this point of order because it is important. Those remarks were questioning the integrity of a High Court judge. It is a tradition of the High Court that, no matter what a judge's background may have been, once he becomes a High Court judge he lifts himself above his previous positions and attitudes. I do not think Mr Justice Murphy's integrity ought to be questioned in that way.

—Senator Walters, I did not understand your remarks to be questioning the integrity of the judges. It is not appropriate to discuss this judgment in that form because it is not relevant to the Bill before us. I would be grateful if you would keep off the subject of the views of the judges.

—I was certainly not querying their integrity in any way, Mr President. If Senator Georges took it that way, I am sorry for him. As the Chief Justice of the High Court has said, there is no area in everyday life, now that that decision has come down, to which those powers cannot be extended. Every area of everyday life of the people of Australia has been influenced by the extension of the powers of the Commonwealth Government. It now has the power to take the rights that every Australian believes were those of the States. This decision was never put to the Australian people as it should have been. But we have learnt that that is not the way in which this Government acts. It is not something the Government believes the people should have any say about.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Government is forced to consult the people, it believes that the people should be brainwashed by allotting extra money to make them see the Government's side of it. We have proof of the Government's attitude in Mr Hawke's history. His Boyer Lectures are proof enough that he believes that all power resides in Canberra. He believes that the external affairs power has nothing to do with the States and is something that he should have. He believes that he should be able to say that the States will accept this. He has already said in his Boyer Lectures that the States are superfluous. He has already said that Canberra should have the ultimate power. We have learnt, in our State particularly, to regret his coming to power. He has attempted to push a republic through the back door. I am extremely opposed to this particular provision that the Minister is putting forward. I appeal to the Australian Democrats to support us in opposing the centralising of power, which these clauses give.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know what you are talking about. You are trying to fill in time.

—Senator Georges is really not making much sense, the way he keeps on interjecting and delaying debate on this Bill. I do not intend to speak at great length. It seems to me that if we do not knock these clauses out, we lay ourselves open for every piece of legislation that has anything to do with international convention to be foisted on every State of this Commonwealth. I believe that would change our Constitution and be a disaster for the people of Australia.

—I am sorely tempted to deal with some of the matters which are raised in the remarks of Senator Harradine and Senator Walters , but I will resist temptation in the spirit of the time and in the hope, of course, that this Bill will go through.
—Congratulations, Senator Missen, for resisting temptation.

—I thank Senator Crowley. I will be voting for the Opposition's amendments in accordance with the Opposition's decision. My views on the use of the external affairs power are well known and unchanged. I made that very clear during the second reading debate speech which I made, actually not on this Bill but on its predecessor, on 8 November 1983. The reasons I gave then for my views still stand.
