SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of the external affairs power in the Sex Discrimination Bill is, as Senator Walters has said, clearly an obvious example of the ambitions of the Federal Labor Government to centralise all power in Canberra. It makes me ask myself what power the Government sees as being appropriate for the States and what power it sees as being appropriate for itself. I really cannot see that the Government draws any distinction between the two, and I am compelled to the view that a Federal Labor Government would take unto itself all power that is available to the States. This Bill is another example of the ambition of the Federal Government to impose its own, perhaps in some ways in the spirit of the Bill, myopic and jaundiced views upon the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: This sort of use of the external affairs powers in this case, in my view, is the result of an assumption on the part of the Federal Government that whatever it can do constitutionally, it may do. The merits, the honesty, the fair dealings and the integrity of the legislation were not relevant to the Government's inquiries, as if the external affairs powers should be used in absolutely all cases. We see no spirit of State-Commonwealth co-operation or goodwill or of seeking to work in a way that will ensure that the structure and the fabric of federalism will continue. I see the use of the external affairs powers in this case as a corruption of the constitutional powers which were intended by the framers of the Constitution. I have no doubt that if the use of the external affairs powers in this sort of case, as in the case involving the South West Tasmanian dam, were put to the people by way of referendum, it would be overwhelmingly defeated.

I fear that in the future the Commonwealth-I am sure this was the intention behind its advisory opinions proposal in the recently aborted referendum legislation-that the Government will seek to use the High Court of Australia as a way of by-passing the people through referenda and so distort the Constitution and ignore it in a way that was never intended, as though it and the views of the great majority of people are irrelevant. If the Federal Government really wanted to test people's views about the use of the external affairs power-it talks about consensus-I dare it to put the proposal to the people of Australia by way of a referendum.

There is no doubt that the individual States have the capacity to introduce and implement legislation of this nature, as they have done on a number of occasions . I do not see this as legislation which necessarily has to be imposed from Canberra. I do not see this as legislation in the nature of the companies and securities exchange legislation. It is legislation that should be introduced by the separate States and implemented in such a way as not to cause contradictions or problems between the various States. The Federal Government is concerned that States such as Queensland and Tasmania will not introduce legislation. Surely that is something for the States to decide. At the appropriate time the people of a particular State will be able to pass judgment upon a State government that did not introduce legislation.

This legislation is but one small step forward in the abuse and by-passing of the Constitution and the politicising in many respects of the High Court. I seriously question how long the fabric and structure of the Federal system as we know it will continue as long as there is abuse of the external affairs powers in this way. As Senator Walters quite clearly and in an articulate fashion put forward, the external affairs powers can be used in many ways. It really saddens me to see a Federal Government that has no concern for States rights or responsibilities but lunges forward, unfettered, with unbridled ambition to impose its view upon the people of Australia, disregarding and having no concern for the States. This just is another example of such a practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government obviously cannot accept the Opposition's amendment in this case . I think it is clear from Senator Martin's remarks that there is a clear policy division between the Government and the Opposition on the appropriateness of the use of the external affairs power. In the Government's view this is a legitimate use of the external affairs power. Of course, the Government is committed to the protection of all Australians, and in doing so will make use of the powers available to it. I should point out, though, that the Bill contains adequate protection for State laws and practices. Clauses 10 and 11 preserve State anti- discrimination laws. The Government leaves open the option for those States which currently do not have such laws to proceed to enact them. When a State does not enact such legislation the Bill will apply. The State laws are preserved by clause 40 for a period of two years, and thereafter regulations made under the legislation can continue this exemption.

SPEECH.PARA: State employees are not covered by this legislation. We are not seeking to make maximum use of the external affairs power and cover state employees in Queensland and Tasmania. At this stage we have left that area of employment to the States. It is quite wrong to try to characterise this piece of legislation, as Senator Crichton-Browne did, as very intrusive. It is true, as Senator Martin pointed out, that the Convention is concerned with discrimination against women and measures to attain equality for men and women. However, it is from women that the majority of complaints come. Accordingly, in the residual areas to which the application of the Convention is relevant, the Bill will have significant impact. It is our view that that significant impact would be seriously eroded should the Opposition's amendment be accepted. Consequently, we cannot accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret the decision of the Labor Government to embark upon a rampage of handing over a wide range of powers to external authorities. It is doing so in such a manner that the whole basis of not only our federal system and States' rights but also the family unit is at stake. Therefore, I very much regret the insertion of these clauses in the Bill. It is rather unfortunate because I believe that, had it not been for the inclusion of these powers, many of us would have supported the legislation. Everyone on this side of the chamber is certainly in favour of overcoming all forms of discrimination against all people, including women. However, as a Tasmanian, I see very clearly the impact that an external affairs power can have on a sovereign community. I just wonder how far this can go, particularly if these external affairs powers can interfere with normal domestic and family arrangements. The implications, although unwritten, are potentially far reaching . Therefore I am in favour of what is proposed by Senator Walters. Also, I regret that, much as I support the principle of abolishing all forms of discrimination, I cannot support the Bill because of its far-reaching provisions .

—I ask the Minister whether sub-clause 15 of clause 9, which deals with banking, would apply to a situation in which a husband and wife were seeking a loan from the Commonwealth Bank. At present that bank will give a loan based on the husband's income only, even though the wife is herself earning a substantial income. Will the Bill, if adopted, apply to that form of discrimination- against the wife's income being taken into account in regard to ability to repay a loan? Also, where a loan has already been taken out, will the parties be able to reapply to have that discrimination done away with?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill covers banking other than State banking-thus it would apply to the Commonwealth Bank-and would prevent the adoption of discriminatory practices with regard to the giving of loans on the basis of sex, marital status and possible pregnancy. If a situation can be defined as discriminatory within the terms of the legislation, a person receiving such treatment would be able to make a complaint to the Human Rights Commission. If it cannot be so defined such a person would not. It is not clear from the example given by Senator Walters whether she is talking about discriminatory practices but, for instance, the Commonwealth Bank could not refuse to give a loan to a person simply on the basis that that person was or was not married. The normal kinds of considerations that banks take into account, such as a person's income, capacity to repay the loan and so on, would not be affected by the legislation. The legislation would say that it is unlawful to refuse a loan simply on the basis that a person is married or unmarried. It would not interfere with the normal criteria that a bank uses when assessing whether it will give a loan or, indeed, the terms and conditions on which the loan is given.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Martin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

Clauses 12 and 13-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 14 (Discrimination against applicants and employees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will be very brief in speaking to this clause because my next amendment is the most vital one. Clause 14 (3) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in paragraph (1) (a) or (b) renders it unlawful for a person to discriminate against another person, on the ground of the other person's sex, in connection with employment to perform domestic duties on the premises on which the first-mentioned person resides.
I move:
(4) Page 12, sub-clause 14 (3), line 12, after 'sex', insert 'or marital status '.

I point out very briefly that the exemption that is contained in that sub-clause is too narrow as it is confined to the acknowledgement of an entitlement to discriminate on the grounds of sex. I ask the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) whether the exemption would permit discrimination against a person living in an open de facto relationship, bearing in mind that this is in the nature of employing people to perform domestic duties and that this legislation, for the first time in the Commonwealth, is placing a de facto relationship on the same basis as a married relationship and forcing individuals to accept that situation. Clause 30 is headed 'Certain discrimination on ground of sex not unlawful' and states:
. . . being a position in relation to which it is a genuine occupational qualification to be a person of the opposite sex to the sex of the other person.

How would the exemption in that clause relate to genuine occupational qualifications? How would the exemptions in clause 35, that is, the residential care of children provision, apply bearing in mind the situation that if one employs people to perform domestic duties in a house of which the owners of the house or of the institution have the responsibility of residential care of children? Finally, how do the exemptions operate in respect of clause 38 ' Educational institutions established for religious purposes'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill provides that it is unlawful to discriminate on the grounds of marital status in the case of employing a couple to do a range of domestic and perhaps maintenance duties in a home. It is the view of the Government that, if a person is applying for employment, his or her capacity to do the job in hand is what is relevant and not marital status. However, as Senator Harradine has pointed out, there are exemptions under clause 35. These apply where:

SPEECH.PARA: the duties of the position involve the care of a child or children in the place where the child or children resides or reside;
Clause 35 (2) (b) grants an exemption where:
it is intended that the spouse of the occupant of the position would also occupy a position as an employee or contract worker of that employer or principal.
That is the area which is exempted. Otherwise marital status would be irrelevant in considering the application for employment in those sorts of domestic duties.

TALK.START.PARA: — In those circumstances I insist on the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I support Senator Harradine's amendment.

Clause agreed to.

Clause 22 (Goods, services and facilities).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 15, after sub-clause 22 (1), insert the following sub-clause:
'(1A) Nothing in Division 1 or 2 renders it unlawful for a person-
(a) to refuse to carry out or participate in carrying out the termination of a pregnancy;
(b) to refuse to provide goods or make available facilities for the termination of a pregnancy; or
(c) to refuse to provide goods, services or facilities for or in relation to the performance of any medical or surgical procedure which that person genuinely believes to be morally wrong.'.

This is a most important-probably the most important-amendment I have. (Quorum formed) Clause 22 relates to the provision of goods, services and facilities. My amendment seeks to add a new sub-clause (1A). As I say, this is a most important measure. I have circularised honourable senators with a letter, dated 14 December, which indicates that there needs to be accepted in the Committee stage certain clarifying language, and that, as far as I am concerned, that needs to be accepted and is necessary to be accepted for me to honour my commitment both to anti-discrimination measures and to pro-life issues. I acknowledge that what the Government has said is that this measure is not designed to be able to be used for the pro-abortion lobby or for persons to make certain demands which would be conducive to the provision of abortion goods, services or facilities.

Clearly, the Government has seen the logic in the argument that in some other areas-for example, in the United States of America-similar types of legislation have been invoked by the pro-abortion lobby to enforce its views on the community in general and on individuals in particular. As far as the provision of services is concerned, the Government, by its amendment in clause 32, has recognised that fact. Clause 32 is headed 'Services for members of one sex'. It states:
Nothing in Division 1 or 2 applies to or in relation to the provision of services the nature of which is such that that they can only be provided to members of one sex.

I shall come to that when we reach that clause. I believe that that is inadequate. But this Bill is aimed at eliminating discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy. As has been stated and, indeed, as has been accepted, in regard to the provision of services, facilities or goods to a woman who, for example, is seeking an abortion, that woman may argue that a doctor does not refuse a non-pregnant woman a service, such as curettage or any other gynaecological procedure or service. That is open to argument that, therefore, that a woman, if she is then denied an abortion, can claim discrimination. Obviously, the Government, as far as services are concerned, has accepted that situation; but it has not done so concerning the provision of goods or facilities. That is the purpose of this amendment.
In circularising honourable senators I also circulated a document that had been prepared by an eminent lawyer and provided to me. That eminent lawyer has asked a number of questions. He said:
It has been claimed that the Government's proposed amendment to clause 32--
which I have read-
of the Bill will remove any possibility of the Bill facilitating abortion practices.
Then he went on:

Clause 22 provides that it is unlawful discrimination to refuse to provide ' goods' 'services' or 'facilities' on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy. The proposed amendment provides that it is not discriminatory to refuse to supply 'services' the nature of which are capable of only being supplied to members of one sex.

As I have said, clearly the amendment does not apply to exempt the supply of goods or facilities. A number of questions must be put to those who consider that the Bill does not in fact allow to occur in the future the situation which has been suggested. In my view the Bill should express in unequivocal language and make it clear that none of its provisions confer rights or impose obligations in relation to the termination of pregnancy. The Government has accepted the question of services. In respect of the provision of goods or facilities, these are the questions which have to be asked: Do the people who say there is nothing wrong with this Bill now concede that goods in clause 22 would include abortifacients such as prostaglandins used for mid-trimester abortions? If the answer to that question is yes, do they agree that it would be discriminatory on the grounds of sex or pregnancy to refuse to supply abortifacients to pregnant women who request them?

If the answer to the first question, that is, do they concede that goods in this clause would include abortifacients, is no-they have to answer either yes or no-on what basis is it claimed that abortifacients are not goods? If the answer to the second question is no, if they have said yes to the first question that they agree that abortifacients are goods, do they agree that it would be discriminatory on the grounds of sex and or pregnancy to refuse such abortifacients to a pregnant woman who requests them? If they say no, on what basis is it said that the refusal is not discriminatory? I have dealt with goods . Another question is: Do they concede that facilities would include the provision of equipment or the physical means for doing something, for example, the provision of suction curettage machines and instruments used in abortions as well as operating theatre availability for the purpose of abortions? If they answer yes to that question-they must answer yes to that question-do they agree that it would be discriminatory on the grounds of sex and/or pregnancy to refuse to make such facilities available for a pregnant woman who requests them? If the answer to that question is no, on what basis is it said that the refusal is not discriminatory? It may be suggested that the refusal to provide such goods or facilities may be based on the grounds of conscience or law. On what clause or legal decision is this suggestion based? It may be said that the law is the law; it is there. I want to know which law. What is the law to which those people refer? That would promote a very interesting debate on various judgments that have been made in respect of these particular matters.

The same question could be raised about the provision of goods. On what basis can a person claim a conscientious objection under this Bill? A number of other matters relating to this issue can be raised at a subsequent stage, but those are the questions that must be answered. If they are not properly answered, why can we not in precise language adopt an amendment such as mine, which would exclude the possibility of this measure being used for purposes for which it was not presumably designed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now dealing with what has been the greatest red herring in this whole debate. It was never the intention or a possibility under the legislation as it was drafted that it could affect in any way current laws regarding access to abortion or to sterilisation operations or to the purchase of abortifacients from pharmacies. It was clear from the definition of discrimination in the Bill that the Bill is concerned with less favourable treatment to persons on the grounds of their sex, marital status or pregnancy.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it was clear from the start that the Bill could cover only services or goods which in their nature could be available to both sexes. One cannot say that it is discriminatory to refuse a man an abortion since in the nature of that service it is not able to be offered to a man. We are being involved in a very confusing red herring which, of course, has gone on to raise some genuine anxieties in the community. However, in order to clarify what was already in the Bill, an amendment to clause 32 was incorporated which clarifies that the Bill does not apply to services the nature of which is that they can be provided only to people of one sex. I should make it clear, because there has been some discussion about this, that sterilisation is a procedure the nature of which can apply only to one sex. Although it is possible for males and females to have sterilisation procedures, those procedures are, of course, entirely different.

TALK.START.PARA: —So each procedure applies only to one sex?
—Yes.
—What about goods and facilities?

—We will come to goods and facilities. Facilities are already covered because clause 32 uses the words 'or in relation to the provision of services the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to members of one sex'. So if the concern is that abortion be clearly excluded and facilities which could be used for an abortion procedure also be excluded, those words cover that.

SPEECH.PARA: For goods, it is a separate question. For goods-abortifacients is the example used by Senator Harradine-the point is that if people do not wish to sell such goods they do not sell them. Abortifacients are goods. A pharmacist has the choice of not stocking them at all or, when selling them, he can warn people and , indeed, should warn customers of the dangers involved in their usage. There is no way the criterion of pregnant or non-pregnant in relation to the customer seeking to purchase the abortifacient could be incorporated in this legislation in the way that Senator Harradine requires. If a pharmacist sells an abortifacient he has no way of knowing who will use it. He could sell it to a man who might then give it to a woman who might wish to use it. We cannot contain what would happen to that good once it was sold by seeking a change to this legislation.

The simple solution is that, if a pharmacist does not wish to stock such goods, there is no obligation on the pharmacist to stock them at all. If a pharmacist refused to stock those drugs, the pharmacist would not commit an act of discrimination under the legislation. The essence of discrimination in clause 5 of the Bill is less favourable treatment on the ground of the sex of a person. A pharmacist who does not stock particular goods is not in a position to supply them to any person, so the sex or marital status of the customer is irrelevant. A further consideration in the refusal by the pharmacist to stock goods could be because of his concern about the nature of the goods and not about the sex of any potential customer. I hope I have clarified that. Senator Harradine raised concerns about the sale of abortifacients by pharmacists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which abortifacients?

—He has not said which ones. I hope I have made it clear that a pharmacist can choose not to sell those goods at all. Such refusal-it could be on the grounds of his moral objection to them-would not constitute discrimination under the Bill. Services and facilities are covered in clause 32 which clarifies that the Bill does not cover services or facilities to or in relation to such services which, in their nature, can only be delivered to one sex. Clearly there are no grounds on which the Government can accept this amendment.

— The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women ( Senator Ryan) has not responded to the questions that I raised in presenting this matter. I raised a series of questions to which she has not responded. In the first place, she indicated that this issue was a red herring. This is not a red herring at all. The Government acknowledges that it is not a red herring by reason of the fact that not only has it amended the original Bill-
—It is a clarification.

—All right, a clarification-but also in respect to the comments which the Minister has just made. She acknowledged that, in the circumstances that arise, there could be a situation whereby this drug could be used for the purposes for which it was not designed. Under those circumstances, why does she not allow this amendment-
—You do not sell it at all. If you have those worries, you do not sell it at all.

—That is the point; one does not sell it at all. A pharmacist may wish to stock certain drugs, He may wish to stock contraceptives. It could well be that a country pharmacist may not wish to provide on conscientious grounds, say, interuterine devices or contraceptives. Is the Minister suggesting that IUDs are not potentially an abortifacient?
—No, I am suggesting they are not sold by pharmacists. My understanding is that they are not.
—Whether they are sold by pharmacists or provided by doctors makes no difference to this clause.
—You are talking about pharmacists in country towns.

—All right, let us talk about doctors in country towns if Senator Tate is interested in the question of conscientious objection. If a doctor has a conscientious objection to the provision of an IUD and if he has a conscientious objection, say, to the provision of contraceptives to a single person, then where does he stand under this legislation? That is the question that one has to ask, and it is not answered. In fact, the other aspect has not been answered as well. Senator Ryan says that this point is a red herring and then she says that the Bill is not designed to alter the current laws on access to abortion. What are the current laws? I would be interested to hear from Senator Ryan what are the current laws in respect of access to abortion.
—States and Territories each have their own.
—I understand what the Minister is saying, but what are the current laws and what are the current interpretations of those laws?
—It is not relevant to this debate.

—It certainly is relevant to this debate. It should not be relevant to the Sex Discrimination Bill and that is why I have designed the amendment-to cover those matters in detail. If neither the Minister nor the Government or any member of it will not support clarifying language, will she give an assurance that nothing in this clause would make it unlawful for a person to refuse to carry out or participate in carrying out the termination of a pregnancy, or to refuse to provide goods or make facilities available for the termination of pregnancy, or to refuse to provide goods, services or facilities for the performance of surgical or medical procedures such as sterilisation, which many people regard as morally wrong? I ask that because the Minister referred to clause 32, and I ask it notwithstanding what is contained in that clause. It is not enough to concede that interpretations are arguable or not arguable; what the Committee needs and certainly what is important for the people of Australia and those who are likely to be affected is an assurance as to how the clause will operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I have been listening carefully to the debate as it has progressed and to the responses of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, to Senator Harradine. The Opposition will support Senator Harradine on this amendment. There are some important issues not covered by the Sex Discrimination Bill, although it might have been meant to cover them. I accept Senator Harradine's contention that clause 32 does not cover all the eventualities he outlined, particularly contraception. Some people-doctors and pharmacists-have a moral objection, for example, to providing the contraceptive pill or whatever to single people. Even if that is not the general community attitude, there are some people who hold that view very firmly and they hold it for moral reasons. Senator Harradine made the point and I do not think the Bill meets that point. There would be a division of views in the Senate on the subject of termination of pregnancy. But I think there would be very little dispute as to whether somebody had the right-let us say a doctor-to refuse to carry out an abortion if the doctor had a moral objection to it. I am sure there would not be any objection to the principle that a nurse who had the same moral objection to abortion refused to participate in or be a part of that procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: So whatever our individual views are on the subject of whether abortion should be illegal, I would expect virtual unanimity-I think it was something that Senator Ryan tried to move towards in the Bill-on the fact that there are a large number of people in our community who believe abortion is morally wrong. I am not one of them, but I respect the point of view, and I respect the grounds on which that view is held. Nevertheless, I doubt that anyone who is of my persuasion-I have outlined in the Senate on previous times that I do not hold the same moral objection to abortion-would disagree with Senator Harradine's amendment; that is, that those who do hold that moral view have a right not to be forced, by the force of any law relating to discrimination, actually to participate in something which morally is utterly unacceptable to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief. Like Senator Martin, I too have listened very carefully to this debate because it is one which particularly interests me. I think my views on abortion are fairly well known. I have certainly always made them clear to the women's movement in South Australia. I am totally opposed to abortion as a form of contraception, unlike Senator Martin, who appears not to share the belief that abortion under any circumstances is morally wrong. However, having said that, I would like to diverge from Senator Martin's other point; that is, I am totally convinced by the Minister's statement that the amendments to clause 32 will satisfy the objections that Senator Harradine put forward in his amendment. It is therefore not the intention of my Party-notwithstanding my views, but because I accept what Senator Ryan has said-to support Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I will not support the further clarification in wording sought by Senator Harradine. I will explain the basis for that. The fact is I believe that those who are listening to this debate ought to understand what is going on. The Government laid open the Bill for public discussion and comment over the winter months. At the end of that period of discussion many representations were made, including those by Senator Harradine and other groups, concerning the question of the possible effect of the Bill in relation to procedures for the termination of pregnancy, and I shared some of those concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst not always agreeing with the particular tactics or political strategies of the right to life movement in Australia, I am a member of the Tasmanian Right to Life Association and I consulted with Margaret Tighe, who is well known to members of the Federal Parliament in relation to her championing of this particular social issue. Indeed, I know, as Chairman of the Caucus legal committee, that during the final discussion of the representations received over the winter a declaratory clarifying clause was inserted into the Bill to become, I think it was then, clause 20 (1A) in order to clarify and declare the situation to make it clear what was already clear, that the Bill did not provide for a situation where it would be unlawful to refuse to provide an abortion to a woman who requested it. That issue is decided on other grounds in relation to other values and laws. This particular Bill had no particular effect on that question. I was nevertheless pleased to see that the Government made yet another more clear statement of that point in what is now clause 32 of the Bill to say that in relation to the whole of Divisions 1 and 2 nothing:
. . . applies to or in relation to the provision of services the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to members of one sex.

Indeed that particular form of language has been the subject of legal advice to the Right to Life Association and Mrs Margaret Tighe has authorised me to table, if that is what honourable senators wish, the legal advice by a leading member of the Melbourne Bar which that particular Association obtained, and which has satisfied itself that indeed this declaratory clarifying section within the Bill does make it quite clear that the Bill does not render the refusal to perform an abortion an unlawful act. Indeed the opinion which has been provided is very striking not only for its sympathetic concern with the issues raised but also for its absolute rejection of the very strange interpretation which has been offered by those who have this concern as a deep moral and conscientious question. Without going through the actual legal steps, step by step-as I say, I am prepared to table the opinion-counsel says at paragraph 2.8:

I have read a number of articles which fear discrimination might arise in the way that is set out in some of the arguments by Senator Harradine and others-but I find their reasoning quite unconvincing.
That is the conclusion of counsel for the Right to Life Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date was that?
—That was in relation to the then clause 20.
—What date was it?
—Well it has been forwarded to me over the last two days.
—What date?
—The date is 30 November 1983.
—Yes, well, a lot of water has flowed under the bridge since then.

—The only water that has flowed under the bridge, Senator, is that as counsel anticipated as a possibility, the Government has gone further than clause 20 and put it in a more embracing context in clause 32. I just indicate that for the benefit of the Committee. Therefore I find it quite unnecessary further to concede to the arousing of fears and misgivings, which Senator Harradine's further amendment I believe sets out to achieve. I believe that the Bill, as it stands, does not in any way permit it to be said that the refusal to provide an abortion to a woman is rendered unlawful by the Bill. I find that the continual attempt to embarrass the Government, to try to put the Government on the defensive and to embarrass Senator Ryan in particular, is a political exercise rather than one that is concerned with the very real issue of whether the Bill does facilitate the termination of pregnancies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Chairman, I object strongly to that comment made by Senator Tate. It comes from a person who accepted the original Bill in its entirety, which left it open--
—That is a complete lie. That is a lie!
—He accepted the original Bill.
—That is a lie!
—Order! Senator Tate, you must withdraw that remark.
—Mr Chairman, in deference to the Chair I withdraw that remark.

—Mr Chairman, Senator Tate accepted the original Bill when it came into the chamber. I am talking about the original Bill which went through Caucus. He accepted that, and furthermore he claimed that persons were concerned about that legislation and their concerns have now been understood and recognised, even by the opinion which in fact is outdated. However, what did Senator Tate do? As far back as 27 October an article headed 'Truth lost in hysteria, says Senator' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The distortion of the Sex Discrimination Bill by some interest groups had contributed to an hysterical atmosphere in which the truth was finding it hard to be heard, Senator Michael Tate said yesterday.
Senator Tate . . . made the comment after supporting the bill in Parliament.
'The bill makes no impact on the question of abortion in Australia whatsoever,' . . .
According to the report, Senator Tate went on to say:

'To make this division crystal clear a declaration has been inserted in the bill stating that nothing in section 20 applies to services, the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to members of one sex.'

I was the one who raised this issue in the first place. I was aware of the fact that it had been used in the United States of America for this purpose. My contacts in America, of whom I have a large number in the pro-life field, had warned of this possibility because the equal rights amendment in the United States had been similarly used. I raised this matter by writing to every senator in this place, including Senator Tate. What Senator Tate is suggesting now is that he and Margaret Tighe got into the act. Margaret Tighe did not even get into the act until I had written to honourable senators. She apparently came up here to lobby and then settled for an arrangement with Senator Tate. That, by definition, even the Government recognised was inadequate because it left hospitals in the Australian Capital Territory, including the Calvary Hospital, open to charges of discrimination under this legislation. Quite clearly, the limiting of the exclusion, such as it is, to the then section 20, was not sufficient. The Government has recognised that because it has in fact amended the legislation, after being pressed by me and others, by inserting new clause 32 which seeks to provide an exclusion for members of one sex in respect of services referred to in Divisions 1 and 2.

Senator Tate says it was his view-presumably he maintains it is still his view- that this issue of abortion is one of the matters that, to use his words, 'are determined in accordance with other values and under particular laws'. He has not answered the questions that have been prepared by legal counsel. He has not answered the questions that I placed before the Senate previously. It is quite clear that this legislation can be used by a person to claim, on the grounds of sex or pregnancy, that he or she has been discriminated against by the refusal to provide certain goods, facilities and services, the nature of which is such that their supply would contravene the conscientious objection of the providers. I know that this gets on to the question of the conscientious clause which I will propose later on and which does not deal precisely with the clause that is currently before us. However, the questions which have been raised, and which have remained unanswered by either Senator Ryan or Senator Tate, are relevant to that clause which we will deal with later. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Gareth Evans will be absent from Question Time today. In his absence I will take any questions which would normally be directed to him. I also inform the Senate that at 12.30 it is my intention to suggest to the Senate that further questions be placed on notice. It is also my intention to move that the Senate sit through lunchtime today and, at the same time, to move that the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2) be declared an urgent Bill with times allocated to particular clauses. I also indicate that all Ministers have agreed that the answers they give to questions will be as short as possible in order to maximise the number of questions asked.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not wish to waste the brief time that we have for questions and other business before the Senate. Just before Question Time, however, Senator Button advised me of his intention to guillotine the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2). In those circumstances I have agreed, on behalf of the Opposition, that we will go along with a shorter Question Time on the clear understanding from Senator Button that that was not to be taken as any sort of precedent and that he would not seek to use it as a precedent. Secondly, we agreed to sit through lunch time . Thirdly, we said that we were opposed to the guillotining of the Sex Discrimination Bill. I made those concessions because the Opposition was told that the Government had the support of the Australian Democrats and therefore the motion for the guillotine would be carried. In those circumstances it is the clear wish of the Opposition that there should be an opportunity to debate the very contentious amendments before us and the Opposition seeks to maximise the time available to us for debate on the Bill.

—by leave-What has been suggested about the guillotining of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2) should not go without challenge. This is not an urgent Bill in its nature. It cannot be finally enacted before the House of Representative deals with it. Senator Button has given notice of a motion-it is on the Notice Paper-for the Senate to sit tonight and tomorrow if necessary. He has now apparently withdrawn that notice or is suggesting that this Bill be guillotined, with the support of the Australian Democrats. That undermines the rights of the Senate.
—Order! The matter Senator Harradine is raising is a matter for debate on the guillotine motion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button, both in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate and as Minister representing the Prime Minister and also in his capacity today as Minister representing the Attorney- General. I remind him of a statement made by the Attorney-General yesterday in the matter of public importance. The Attorney said that the difficulty is that there is simply no established policy in place at the moment with regard to the dry docking of warships which may be armed with non-conventional weapons; that discussions were set in place between the United States and our British allies in regard to this matter; and that the discussions he was contemplating would take months rather than days or weeks. I also refer Senator Button to statements reportedly made by the Prime Minister on a radio program last night. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I would think in respect of the United States the matter is resolved-they understand, and there'll be no problem there. There's a bit more discussion going on with the UK.
How can these statements be reconciled? What is the true position? Are the talks continuing with the United States as well as the British Government, as indicated by Senator Evans yesterday?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the matter, there have been discussions with both governments. According to the latest information I have, they have been expedited and probably will not take as long as Senator Evans foreshadowed in his speech yesterday. I am unable to provide precise details of the discussions with the United States, but I think it is probably true to say that they are resolved or reaching a point of finality. I know that further discussions have taken place with the British Government. I am instructed that the Minister for Defence, as at yesterday, was having talks with the British Minister for Defence about this matter. But on the basis that those discussions are not finally completed, I am not in a position to add any more by way of enlightenment in respect of this matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. In view of the fact that in 1981 women in Australian universities constituted only 19 per cent of staff at the level of lecturer and 2 per cent at the level of professor, can the Minister comment on the publicly stated opinion of Dame Leonie Kramer that 'the most important academic procedures-selection and promotion-are, in intention and overwhelmingly in operation, scrupulously equitable'? Is it reasonable to suggest, in the words of Dame Leonie, that women who wanted to raise a family could not then expect to reach the highest rungs of the academic ladder? How could such a prominent and highly qualified woman hope that the campaign for women's participation in academic life will not be too successful?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The views of Dame Leonie Kramer, as they were reported in the media , have been drawn to my attention. I can only express my disappointment that a woman in such an eminent academic position as Dame Leonie should express her wish, if indeed she has, that our policies of making universities and promotions within universities more accessible to women of appropriate qualifications and expertise should fail.

ANSWER.PARA: The implications of Dame Leonie Kramer's remarks are quite disturbing. If she believes that there is not any structural discrimination against women academics , one must infer from her expressing that view that she also believes that the current situation in which only 2 per cent of professors are women reflects the real capacity of women. That is certainly not my view. It is not the view of any organisation representing women academics, be it the Australian Federation of University Women or the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, or any other organisation that has high membership of university women. It is the view of those organisations that in the past a great deal of direct and indirect discrimination has prevented women of very high qualifications of outstanding scholarship and teaching experience from receiving promotion to the most senior levels within the academic hierarchy. I refer honourable senators to a study made of women within universities called 'Why so few' which was published last year and which documents very convincingly the kinds of employment policies, promotional policies and circumstances that have prevented very able women from being made professors. For example, I recall that at the Melbourne University an outstanding woman academic, Dame Margaret Blackwood, was denied a chair for many--

TALK.START.PARA: —Short answers.

—Sorry. Senator Chaney reminds me I should be giving a short answer . Dame Margaret Blackwood was denied a chair for many years, despite the fact that the entire academic community and her academic peers considered her to be the most outstanding person in her field. I am reminded by the Leader of the Opposition that we have an agreement on short answers. I simply express my disappointment and my disagreement and can only hope that Dame Leonie has been inaccurately reported.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who I think is representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the question I asked the Attorney-General on Tuesday this week concerning the expenditure of funds for the promotion of the Yes case from the $1.25m allocated by the Government for this exclusive purpose prior to the disallowance agreed to by the Senate yesterday. The Attorney-General undertook to try to give me an idea of the money that had been expended prior to our disallowance. Is the Leader of the Government in a position to provide the Senate with the costs of the information kits that were paid for prior to the debate in the Senate? I note also that some 10,000 booklets were published. Is he able to provide any information about that? Also is he able to inform the Senate of the costs incurred with respect to the consultation with advertising agencies and the market surveys that were conducted? Will the Leader of the Government table all the documents, including the booklet to which I referred in the Senate today?

—There are a number of parts to the honourable senator's question and I am not surprised that the Attorney-General has not been able to answer them between Tuesday and Thursday. I understand the information has been sought and will be provided to Senator Jessop as soon as possible. I regret that that is the only undertaking that I can give at this stage.
—Mr President, very quickly, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from that answer that the Leader of the Government will be giving me a written reply?
—I am sure that a written reply-I am not sure that it will be adequate for Senator Jessop-will be provided.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the latest monthly figures on retail sales, which indicate a substantial increase in sales in the month of October, and to recent predictions by the Australian Retailers Association of a bumper Christmas shopping season. I ask: In what way have the Government's economic policies contributed to this massive boost in consumer confidence? Can we expect this increase in activity in the retail industry to flow through to other sectors of the economy in 1984?

—There is no doubt that the stability which the Government has provided to economic policy is a major factor in the recovery in the various sectors to which Senator Foreman has referred. I gave a detailed answer to a similar question, I think about three days ago, and in view of the constraints which have been requested about short answers I refer Senator Foreman to that answer for more detail.

—I was looking forward with relish to asking the Attorney-General this question but in his absence I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it not a fact that the Prime Minister stated in the Australian Labor Party's campaign speech of last February that the very circumstances of the calling of this panic election reek of fraud and deception, and went on to question why the election was being called eight months before time? Why now, only nine months after being elected and nine months after making that scathing attack on Mr Fraser for his political expediency in calling an early election, is the Prime Minister speculating on calling an early election, 16 months before it is due? Does not the Prime Minister's claim of a recalcitrant Senate reek of fraud and deception, given that out of the 169 pieces of legislation presented to the Senate all but four have been passed or remain intact to be passed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp in other circumstances has reminded me that he was a member of parliament when I was still at school, or something like that.
—He was at school for a very long time.

—Seven years in fourth form, yes. I think Senator Chipp will recall that frequently these statements are made, particularly at this time of the year when the Senate blocks or otherwise delays particular pieces of legislation. I think they are always made by politicians of various political persuasions. I do not think they can be construed as speculation about an early election.

ANSWER.PARA: I concede in part Senator Chipp's observation that the Senate, except with particular Bills, has not been a highly recalcitrant Senate. I do not know, but it is just possible that the Prime Minister might have speculated about an early election in order to help the economic recovery even further, because speculation about an early election carries with it speculation about the prospect of the alternative government succeeding in that election. That would be a great stimulus to the people of Australia to follow the Government's economic policies which are leading to such success. Insofar as I am unable to answer parts of the question, I will address them to the Prime Minister and obtain an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to a story in today's Age describing recent oil discoveries in the Naccowlah block in south-west Queensland by Claremont Petroleum? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the significance of these discoveries? Is it feasible for the oil produced to be piped through the Moomba pipeline to the Stony Point terminal in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in today's Age which is headed 'New oil find could yield 450m barrels'. I am advised that the reference to 450m barrels is not soundly based and is not even close to an accurate figure. The proven reserves in that entire area amount to about 50m barrels. I am not in a position to allocate blame, but somebody has shamelessly talked up the figure for whatever reason. The evidence available today can confirm only 50m barrels.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of other misleading statements in that story. Tinpilla has not yet been declared an oil discovery. Jackson oil is being trucked to Moonie at present and is not piped to Adelaide. The map in the Age incorrectly shows Jackson as located in South Australia. So it is a highly unreliable story, to say the least.

As to the final part of Senator Maguire's question as to whether it is feasible that oil from the Jackson field which, I stress, is in Queensland and not in South Australia, as the map in today's Age shows, could be piped to Adelaide, that certainly could be done. I understand that Santos Ltd originally wanted to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that because of the peanut curtain, Senator?

—That is right, yes. It could not penetrate the peanut curtain. The pipeline was not allowed to pass the peanut curtain into Queensland and as a result a very much more extensive investment in the pipeline to Brisbane had to be made. If a rational approach to planning for the development of the whole area had been applied, unimpeded by interstate jealousies, the oil that has been discovered so far could have been delivered by pipeline to Adelaide.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It follows Senator Jessop's question about the money already spent on the referendum cases. Have the kits that have been produced been distributed? If so, how widely?

—I believe that the kits have not been widely distributed, but I am unable to give a more precise answer. Of course, as I indicated to Senator Jessop, I will make sure that Senator Walters gets an answer to this question.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Since the Senate may rise today, and in a week Christmas will be upon us , does the Leader of the Government have a message for the growing thousands of individuals and their families who, on Amnesty International figures, have been imprisoned or tortured, have disappeared or been murdered in over 60 countries of the world for exercising their basic human rights? Could the Leader of the Government also express the Government's attitude to the fundamental and shameful economic injustice in that at least one-fifth of the world's population lives in poverty and that inequality between the rich and the poor is still rampant?

—I share Senator Cook's concern about this matter. The Brotherhood of St Laurence recently estimated that some two million to three million people in Australia could be described as poor. The World Bank report of 1978, which was the last report of the World Bank to deal with this topic, indicated that 800 million people in the world live in absolute poverty and almost one-fifth of the world's people-three billion people-can be described as poor. I do not know what message I can deliver on behalf of the Government to those people except to express concern, which I feel is shared by all honourable senators, and the hope that Australia will be able to make an enlarging contribution to relieving this problem in the future. That, of course, depends on our priorities and our capacity to have this economy generate greater wealth, some of which might be contributed to those purposes.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the recent elevation to the inner Cabinet of his colleague Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industry. Since Mr Kerin has had most of his submissions on behalf of primary industry knocked back, and is travelling rural Australia saying sadly to primary industry 'I agree with you, but Cabinet won't listen,' will Senator Button use his considerable clout in Cabinet to allow Mr Kerin a small face- saving win on some minor submission to restore his self-confidence, which has been absolutely destroyed?

—First of all, it is not correct to say that the majority of Mr Kerin's submissions to Cabinet are knocked back. I think the burden of Senator Boswell's question really is that Mr Kerin is a highly successful and well regarded Minister for Primary Industry. If the National Party finds that unpalatable, I am sorry. That is bad luck.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill debated in this place on Wednesday. I ask the Minister: What is the correct position in respect of the Acts Interpretation Act and its effect on taxpayers who may have requested exemption from tax liability pursuant to the provisions of this legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The correct position is that before anyone could request exemption from tax liability under section 3 (12) of the present Act, that person would have to be in receipt of an assessment or make such a request during the subsequent objection period. That is in conflict, of course, with the reason that Senator Harradine gave on Wednesday, when he voted against precisely the same proposition which he had voted for last year. Senator Harradine claimed, and repeated yesterday, that he voted in the way he did because of the retrospective effect. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the omission of section 3 (12) has a retrospective effect in that taxpayers who would be entitled to relief under that sub-section and who have requested that it be applied by the Commissioner of Taxation will now have that right removed and face recoupment tax liability.

As a matter of law, pursuant to section 8 of the Acts Interpretation Act, Senator Harradine is wrong. Anybody who made such a request would be exempt from liability whether section 3 (12) remained in the existing Act or not. In other words, there is absolutely no substance in the reason which Senator Harradine gave for reversing his vote and no substance in the claim he made yesterday that he had been misrepresented on this issue by the Press. Senator Harradine could have got that information at any time before Wednesday by means of a simple telephone call to the Australian Taxation Office. There is one other matter I wish to raise before completing the answer. I note that on Wednesday last Senator Harradine said:
Does the Government want me to move an amendment to amend this Bill in precisely the same terms as the first Bill? If it wants me to do so, I will test it out and I will do it . . .

that is, move an amendment. Subject to Senator Harradine confirming, either in the Senate or in writing, that undertaking which he gave on Wednesday and adding that he would vote for such an amendment, having moved it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the Minister that the answer is getting a bit long.

—I am almost finished, Mr President. If Senator Harradine moves an amendment effectively to enact the original May Bill, I will take his guarantee to the Treasurer and/or to Cabinet and suggest that the Government act accordingly.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to his repeated promises to release a Green Paper on resource rent tax before Christmas. I ask: Is it still his intention to release such a paper before Christmas? If not, when does he expect it to be released? Could he indicate shortly whether the delay in releasing the Green Paper indicates that the Government has realised that the proposal has very real practical problems as opposed to the pure economic theory on which the tax is based?

—It is still my intention and hope to release the Green Paper before Christmas. Senator Chaney or anyone else who is interested is entitled to know that a draft has been prepared. That draft is satisfactory to me; but, prior to releasing it, I need to check that it is satisfactory to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister. Subject to the Treasurer having time to look at it between now and, say, the middle of next week, I hope to release it in the middle of next week. I do not believe the Treasurer will have any problems with it. The second question Senator Chaney asked has been partly covered but I will make one brief comment. There are certainly some technical problems in implementing the proposal. I have never attempted to deny those problems; but the Government has not dropped the proposal because of those technical problems, nor does it believe that those technical problems are insurmountable.

—Is the Minister representing the Special Minister of State aware that there were a number of problems with mobile polling during the Northern Territory election? In particular I refer to the lack of a notification period before a change of poll site or visit time, lack of thought given to location and duration of mobile polls and problems associated with mobile polls being placed on pastoralists' properties. Will the Minister investigate these problems in order that they do not occur during the next Federal election? I remind the Minister that this could now be a matter of urgency following the decisions made yesterday.

—Those complaints about the Northern Territory election are a matter of public knowledge. Attention has been drawn to them in the Press. I will convey the contents of Senator Sibraa's question to the Special Minister of State. I am sure he will look into the matter and provide an early answer. I will also look into the matter in respect of the Commonwealth situation following general reviews which are taking place as a result of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I ask: Will any Australian television network broadcast the United States produced television film depicting the effects of nuclear war, The Day After? In particular, has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation sought to obtain this program and, in terms of my question on notice No. 545, show it in prime time nationally and with adequate publicity?

—I am indebted to Senator Mason for his question. I recall the previous question which he asked me. I am able to supply him with an answer. The answer is that exclusive television rights to the film are being purchased by the commercial network, Channel 10. The time of screening is for that network to determine. I am further advised that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation tried to obtain television rights to the film but was unsuccessful. I also understand that cinema rights for Australia for the film are being held by Roadshow Distributors Pty Ltd, which plan to commence box office sales in February 1984.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate who is representing the Attorney-General, concerns the Human Rights Commission education course entitled 'Teaching Human Rights-Activities for Schools'. Can the Minister say when the course will be taught in schools on a national level? Can he also advise whether non-government schools are likely to include the course in their curriculum?
—I am not able to supply that information but I will ensure that the Attorney writes to Senator Elstob concerning it as soon as possible.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, by referring him to the package of steel legislation that was passed in the Senate yesterday. EMPLOYMENT: WOMEN APPRENTICES

On 7 December 1983 Senator Crowley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning employers attitudes to women apprentices.
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided me with further information on this matter.

I am advised that the grants for the study of employer attitudes to employing women apprentices in traditionally male trades, referred to by the honourable senator, were approved by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and funded through the Bureau of Labour Market Research. The BLMR exercise is being undertaken because there are no Australian studies of employers' attitudes towards women apprentices in non-traditional areas.

I understand that the attitude of employers towards female apprentices is only one of the factors that has limited the number of female apprentices in training today. Other important factors which influence female participation in the trades include:
lack of awareness by females of the career and educational opportunities associated with the trades.
misconceptions of the working environment which is traditionally male-dominated .
community prejudices, family and peer pressures against female participation in the trades.
secondary education not oriented for entry into the trades.

In so far as Government action is concerned, in an attempt to overcome some of the barriers related to the willingness of females to participate in the trades and to demonstrate to employers that females have the ability to undertake trade work, Government labour force programs in the trade area have as part of their objective the provision of employment and training opportunities for females.
Two such schemes are the Group Apprenticeship Scheme and the Government's recent initiative to fund an additional 3,000 trade-based pre-employment course places in TAFE in 1984.
In negotiating with State and Territory Governments the range and levels of Federal Government assistance under these programs, the Government actively seeks to maximise opportunities for females.

Honourable senators will recall that the National Economic Summit Conference agreed that the move towards greater equality and independence for women should be encouraged and that there should be equal access to job creation programs, to employment, training, retraining and education, and measures designed to break down occupational segregation and discrimination.

The Sex Discrimination Bill which has recently been debated in the Senate will render discrimination against women in the spheres of education, training and employment unlawful. The Affirmative Action Green Paper will include information to assist employers in the formulation of equal employment policies within their organisations and enterprises. The National Labour Consultative Council has previously published ''Guidelines for Employers on Equal Employment Opportunities for Women'', which provides some advice for employers intending to implement such a policy.

The Women's Bureau in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has produced several videos promoting career opportunities for women in a range of non-traditional occupations. The most recent video entitled ''Technically Speaking'' has been produced in two parts, one of which is intended for viewing by employers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following additional information relating to the BLMR report:

EXECUTION OF CRIMINALS IN INDONESIA

On 2 December 1983 Senator Missen asked a question concerning the killing of criminals and suspected criminals in Indonesia by mysterious death squads. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer: I am aware of reports of a major campaign against crime in Indonesia and that it is alleged that the campaign is officially condoned. According to some estimates, between 2 ,000 and 3,000 people involved or alleged to have been involved in criminal activities have been shot without trial by so-called ''death-squads''.
The campaign is alleged to have started in Yogyakarta in May and subsequently extended to other important urban areas in Java, Sumatra and Kalimantan.

On my instructions, the Australian Ambassador in Jakarta made representations about the allegations to the Indonesian Government on 16 August. The issue has also been raised on a number of occasions with Indonesian officials.

Australia is concerned about outbreaks of lawlessness but could not and would not condone summary executions which would be in clear contravention of the fundamental human rights embodied in the Universal Declaration on Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The Government has consistently taken the view that Australia has a strong interest in seeing internationally accepted human rights observed and respected, and believes that in all situations the due process of law should be followed. Our representations to the Indonesian authorities are in keeping with this interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps only one thing has been said in these last few minutes with which the Opposition would agree: That is, we want to see full and fair consideration of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2). We do not believe that the motion moved by the Government does, in fact, fit in with that objective. In fact, the only result of the Senate passing this Bill will be that the Bill will be in limbo between the Senate and the House of Representatives for several months before it is dealt with by the House of Representatives, and, perhaps, dealt with in a rather peremptory way by that chamber if this is any example of the Government's attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: We dispute the assertion that this is an urgent Bill. We do not believe that it is urgent, for the reason that I have indicated. What is urgent is that the inconvenience of the Bill should be removed from honourable senators opposite, because the Bill has been the subject of a great number of representations from around Australia and I have little doubt that Government senators want to see the matter off their agenda before they go away for Christmas. I suspect that that is the reality that lies behind the motion.

I have at all times made it clear to the Government, and I have had a number of discussions with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that we could not agree to the guillotining of the Sex Discrimination Bill because we regard the legislation as of considerable social significance and we think that it is essential that there be full and fair opportunity for debate. We have a Bill which the Government itself has amended over 50 times. It has introduced over 50 amendments. There are over 30 amendments being put by the Opposition. A small number of those have been dealt with. We are now in a situation in which we have to debate the remaining 27 amendments which have been put forward by the Opposition, by the Australian Democrats and by Senator Harradine.

The fact of the matter is that there is no urgency about the Bill. We are being given a little over three hours in which to deal with 27 amendments. That is about eight minutes per amendment. Even if there is some grouping of amendments, there will be very little opportunity for a substantial debate on issues of some moment. We are still to debate amendments to the harassment provisions and to the education provisions, and amendments to the administrative arrangements which are being put in place on such questions as the rights of people to have a lawyer, the extent to which schools are to be exempt, and the extent to which there should be a conscience provision in the Bill. We face a very difficult task in dealing with what are complex amendments on a matter of very wide public interest within the sort of time frame which has been laid down by the Government.

One can understand the Government wanting to clear its legislative program and a lack of concern because it has given the matter internal consideration. No doubt members of the Government believe that the legislation is in proper form and are asking themselves why they should be worried about further parliamentary time. One can understand that. One can understand the Manager of Government Business, Senator Grimes, saying: 'After all, the Bill has already had 13 1/2 hours'. The fact is that most of that time has been taken up in second reading debate. We have had very limited time in Committee. The fact is that this is a Bill which has excited great public comment and on which serious issues of principle have been raised. The surprising thing is not the Government's attitude. Governments in the past have moved the guillotine. I was once a Whip, and I managed to get a few Government senators at that time to support the guillotine. I concede that, although I would mention that Senator Sir John Carrick, when Leader of the Government in the Senate, never once, I think--

TALK.START.PARA: —Once.

—Once; used once the procedure that is now before us. But the surprise card in this pack is not Senator Grimes. It is my friend Senator Chipp, because Senator Chipp said to the Australian people that one of the great advantages of electing Australian Democrats to this place is that there would be no more gags and no more guillotines. That is a view which I have often heard repeated in this place, and I am sure that Senator Chipp and the Democrats remember that famous statement of Senator Chipp's. I guess that it goes to show that what a politician says in one circumstance will not necessarily be applicable to another circumstance in which he finds himself. The limitations which are being placed on this debate are being placed on it by the Government, and they are also being placed on it by the Australian Democrats, who indicated that under them, that would not occur. Obviously, the people of Australia cannot rely on the Democrats to ensure that there is an opportunity for full and fair debate in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may say something which I hope will strike a wider chord of agreement in the Committee, because whilst I am sure that Opposition senators agree with what I am about to say, it is clear that neither the Government senators nor the Democrats agree with it. I believe that there is no point-no doubt we shall hear from the Democrats-in debating for the next hour the issues which are before us now. I think the time that is available to us should certainly be spent on the Committee stage of the sex discrimination legislation. I would like to make it clear that we have agreed to forgo the lunch break and we have agreed to the shorter Question Time because it is the view of the Opposition that there should be the maximum opportunity to consider the issues of principle which have been raised and, importantly, to vote on the clauses as they arise.

I wish to acknowledge that in the representations that I made to the Government there has been a response in that the form of guillotine which has been put down does break up the time and should give us some hope that the actual amendments which are being put forward can be put to a vote. I think it is important that that should be so. The Opposition will do its best to ensure that the proceedings of the Committee operate in a way which will enable that to happen. I acknowledge that one virtue in the form of guillotine which has been put down by the Government. A guillotine in gross would have had the effect whereby all divisions might have been taken in one vote and those honourable senators who might have wished to vary their position on the different aspects of this legislation would have been denied that important right.

I wish to express the concern of the Opposition that, in a situation which is devoid of real urgency, in a situation where the Bill cannot in fact be dealt with totally by the Parliament until well into next year, the Government has seen fit to put this limitation on the time which is available for debate. I wish, in the firmest possible terms, to make known the total objection of the Opposition to the procedure which is before us.

''(2) A person shall, for the purposes of this section, be taken to sexually harass another person if-
(a) the first-mentioned person makes a sexual advance, or a request for sexual favours, to the other person, or engages in other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the other person;
