These amendments refer to the sexual harassment provisions of the Sex Discrimination Bill. I reassure Senator Walters that in moving any of my amendments I intend to take the minimum time that I think is necessary to state the Opposition's case and to avoid unnecessary elaboration. I am sure that is the spirit of all speakers today. Amendment No. (7) seeks to amend clause 28 (3) by substituting a new sub-clause (3) to provide that a person would be guilty of sexual harassment of someone else in the following circumstances:
(a) the first-mentioned person makes a sexual advance, or a request for sexual favours, to the other person, or engages in other conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the other person;
(b) the other person-
presumably the person being harassed-
takes reasonable steps to communicate to the first-mentioned person that the advance, request or conduct is unwelcome; and
(c) (i) the first-mentioned person-
that is, the alleged harassor-
makes it reasonably appear to the other person that a rejection of the advance, a refusal of the request or the taking objection to the conduct would disadvantage the other person-
the harassee-
in any way in connection with the other person's employment or work or possible employment or possible work; or
(ii) as a result of the other person's-
the harassee's-
rejection of the advance, refusal of the request or taking of objection to the conduct, the other person is disadvantaged in any way in connection with the other person's . . .

I think the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, knows what I mean, and I am sure the Committee knows. We seek to put a provision here that it should be clear that the harassment, whatever form it takes-whether it is a request for sexual favours or whatever, but something of a sexual nature-is not welcome. I know we get into the difficult situation where some would say it could be alleged that sometimes through fright or fear, a young woman might just freeze, emotionally, and not know how to handle the situation, particularly if the person doing the harassing is someone who is older, more senior or perhaps the boss. Therefore the woman involved might appear to encourage the person making the sexual advance by, say, smiling, which is something that people do on occasion in nervous fright-it is possible-or perhaps try to ignore the problem, hoping it will go away. I know that that is one argument.

The alternative, where that distaste for the sexual advance, or the annoyance or fear that may be felt by that person in relation to the sexual advance, is not expressed in any way, could well lead to the classic defence used down through the ages: 'But I thought she liked it'. I think there is a grey area. It is probably difficult for certain men on occasions, unless they are given an indication, to realise that they are not being encouraged. It is difficult for some men, even if someone hits them on the head with a lump of wood, to be discouraged. But that is an aside; it has nothing to do really with sexual harassment. There could genuinely be a man who is attracted to someone with whom he works, someone who may be junior to him, who makes a sexual advance and believes that he has been encouraged. He does not make the sexual advance with menace or with the thought that 'I will use my position of superiority to have my evil way with this young lass whether she wants it or not'.

The difficulty of the present Bill is that it leaves this element in the mind of the person being harassed and, to a certain extent, of the person doing the harassing. I think it is necessary that the person who would make a complaint under this clause should give something that can be taken as an indication. It would not necessarily be taken as an indication, as I said a few minutes ago, by that particular individual. It may be that the girl would say: 'Keep your rotten hands to yourself'. As I said, there are some men who would take that as encouragement because of the saying that some men like to believe that, when a woman says 'No' she really means 'Yes' and who would proceed on that assumption. But if the girl did say that, or if she has done something to indicate that the advance is unwelcome, it is no defence for him to choose to misinterpret that indication.

This is probably the most aggravating clause of the Bill. That has been clear from the second reading debate and it has been clear from a lot of the nonsense during the second reading debate. A man opening a door for a woman was one example of harassment that one senator gave; and there were other such examples. Clearly, many men do not have any idea of what is harassment. That was shown in the second reading debate. This will be an area of the Bill that will cause a great deal of agitation and worry. The hope of the Opposition in moving these amendments is that we will be able to take out of the Bill something which appears to be of a one-sided nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked by the Opposition to indicate at each clause whether the Australian Democrats intend to oppose or to support the amendments, in order merely to clarify things for the Opposition when it comes to calling divisions. I assure you, Mr Chairman, that this in no way cuts across our signalling system. But it is a matter of convenience for the Opposition. I say on these two amendments that the Democrats will not support the Opposition. We will not support the Opposition because, no matter what Senator Martin says, these two amendments significantly weaken the sexual harassment provisions of the Bill. It took some of us some considerable effort in the first place to strengthen the provisions in the original Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In plain English, what the Opposition appears to be saying in these two amendments is this: Sexual harassment is when a person makes an explicit sexual advance of some sort; the other person then takes 'reasonable' steps to communicate that the advance or conduct, et cetera is unwelcome; and the harasser must make it 'reasonably' clear that the rejection of the advance would disadvantage the person in connection with that person's employment or that, as a result of rejection of the advance, that person would be disadvantaged in connection with that person's employment. That, of course, makes nonsense of Senator Martin's example of a man who is operating with no malice, because, if he is operating with no malice, quite clearly he has no intentions of prejudicing her employment or her advancement and, therefore, has no case to answer under the Act. So I am a little puzzled as to why Senator Martin brought up that particular example.

The other question that needs to be raised, of course, is what exactly is ' reasonable'. Senator Martin, I must admit, pointed out that there is a problem in this regard. What is reasonable to one person is not reasonable to another. As Senator Martin said, some men have to be hit over the head with a lump of wood before they can be persuaded that one really does not like them. In essence , however, the major problem with these amendments is that sexual harassment appears to be seen as an accepted art form, or piece of human behaviour, or at the very least they are saying: 'OK, have a go and see how far you get'. It perpetuates the power games that we have all been trying to end, in which first the oppressor does the harassing, the oppressed person reacts and then the power goes back once more to the oppressor, because, of course, it is the harasser who is given the right in this circumstance to decide whether the advance will affect the other person's job or future. Most importantly, these two amendments by the Opposition beg the whole question: If a woman believes that by not acceding to an advance she will be disadvantaged in her employment by the person making the advance, she will hardly believe that communicating the fact that she does not like the advance-or that the advance is unwelcome, that she does not like the person, or that she is not feeling like it today-or whatever-will not also disadvantage her. So the whole question is totally begged by the two amendments and the Democrats will most definitely oppose them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I ask Senator Harradine whether he would also like to speak on this matter, because my judgment is that we have a few minutes left.
—Yes, I support the amendments; that is all.

—I want to share the time and I certainly want the Minister to have time to reply. The Government has said that it is up to the woman to decide whether she has been sexually harassed. The Government is not abiding by the Victorian legislation. Indeed, our amendments follow word for word the Victorian legislation. I do not understand why the Government will not accept our amendments because they have been set out in accordance with the provisions of the Victorian legislation. They say, purely and simply, firstly that the woman must demonstrate to the man who is supposedly sexually harassing her that his advances are unwelcome-that is all we ask; that she tell him that they are unwelcome-and, secondly, if there is some sort of hold over the woman as regards her job, that it also be indicated that she is concerned about the hold over her job. All I can say is that, if a woman is not prepared to indicate verbally that the advances are unwelcome, I do not believe she has a right to accuse him at a later date of sexual harassment. It cannot be in the mind of the woman alone, as this Bill indicates. We cannot legislate for thinking alone, and to attempt to do so is ridiculous. TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Chairman, the Government does not accept the amendments moved on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Martin for the reasons really that I think were set out very clearly by Senator Haines. Many of the women we are hoping will be protected by this legislation are women who may be migrants and have a poor command of English, or be very young or be in a very inferior position in the work force and would not be in a position to articulate in a way that the harasser found reasonable her objection. Senator Martin agrees that this is often a very difficult thing to do, even when extremely articulate women are doing it. So I think Senator Haines's point about the difficulties this would create for women is our view also. But I would point out too that in both of the clauses to which Senator Martin has moved amendments it is required that the other person has reasonable grounds for believing that a rejection of the advance would disadvantage that person in connection with his or her employment or in connection with his or her education. So it is not just social sexual harassment, it is harassment in connection which would cause disadvantage in employment and education. Obviously a man, or maybe a woman-but it is more likely to be a man-who was doing that, knowing that he could cause disadvantage to that person's education or employment could not be acting innocently in that situation. —Mr Chairman, could the Minister say in whose opinion? Would it be in the mind of the person being harassed or in the mind of the employer? I am asking the Minister if she could let us know how it can be distinguished what goes on in the mind of either the employer or the woman in this case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ADVICE
Re: Sex Discrimination Bill 1983

1.1 There is presently before the Commonwealth Parliament a Bill entitled the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (''the Bill''). The central provisions of the Bill prohibit discrimination against another person on the grounds of that person's sex, marital status or pregnancy.
1.2 Section 5 relates to sex discrimination:
''(1) For the purposes of this Act a person (the discriminator) discriminates against another person (the aggrieved person) on the ground of the sex of the aggrieved person if by reason of-
(a) the sex of the aggrieved person;
(b) a characteristic that appertains generally to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person; or
(c) a characteristic that is generally imputed to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person;

the discriminator treats the aggrieved person less favourably than in circumstances that are the same or are not materially different the discriminator treats or would treat a person of the opposite sex.''

1.3 Sub-sections 6 (1) and 7 (1) refer to discrimination on the ground of marital status and pregnancy respectively and are substantially the same, although in s.7 (1) (b) a discrimination does not occur if the less favourable treatment is reasonable in the circumstances.

1.4 I am briefed to advise the Right to Life Association (Vic.) (''the Association'') in respect of the Bill. I must say that I have also been approached formally and informally by a number of organisations and persons seeking views upon particular aspects of the Bill. In some cases the persons seeking that advice have had common interests. I am concerned only with the provisions of the Bill in a legal sense which relate to abortion. But I recognise there are probably other parts of the Bill than those I deal with which are unsatisfactory in a legal or social sense. I do not concern myself with those aspects.
Clauses 20 and 24
2.1 It has been said that clause 20 makes it an offence for a person to refuse to provide an abortion or abortion services. Clause 20 reads:

''(1) It is unlawful for a person who ........ provides goods or services or makes facilities available, to discriminate against another person on the ground of the other person's sex, marital status or pregnancy:
(a) by refusing to provide the other person with those goods or services or to make those facilities available to the other person.''
2.2 Services are defined in section 4 as including:
''(d) Services of the kind provided by any members of profession or trade;''

2.3 The argument for the above construction (as I understand it) goes as follows . A doctor can provide the service of abortion. This is so. Many abortions are performed throughout the States of Australia which allegedly comply with existing law.
2.4 But there are many doctors who (notwithstanding such an abortion is not a criminal offence) conscientiously object to performing abortions and will refuse to do so.

2.5 What, I understand, is feared is that if clause 20 is enacted the doctor who refuses to perform a ''lawful abortion'' will constitute that doctor a discriminator against the aggrieved person, being the mother.

2.6 Presumably it will be said that because the aggrieved person requiring an abortion is pregnant she has a characteristic appertaining to the female sex and therefore the doctor is using that fact to discriminate against her.

2.7 But how can it be said that the doctor is treating her less favourably than he would a person of the opposite sex in circumstances that are the same or not substantially different. The fact of the alleged discrimination ''namely the abortion of a foetus'' depends upon a circumstance (pregnancy) which just does not happen to a man. How can it then be said the discriminator treats or would treat a person of the opposite sex differently. By definition the discriminator cannot treat or refuse to treat a male by way of performing or refusing to perform an abortion.

2.8 I have read a number of articles which fear such discrimination might arise but I find their reasoning quite unconvincing. I understand fears are also held that persons potentially administering the Act might interpret s.20 this way. If this be so it is a sad commentary upon such persons and it must also imply a deficiency in appellate or review procedures.

2.9 Likewise it seems to me obviously wrong to say that because a doctor refuses to perform an abortion he is discriminating in the sense that he would treat a person who is not pregnant differently. Once again it seems to me that the circumstance of pregnancy is a fundamental distinguishing factor. It is a case of ''apples and oranges''. One does not perform an abortion on or give advice or services in respect of abortion to a person who is not pregnant. If a doctor says 'I refuse to abort a pregnant woman' that is a discrimination against the operation of abortion. It is a contradiction in terms to say that a doctor would treat a person who is not pregnant differently-he would not treat her at all.

3.1 I have difficulty in understanding the argument and to the extent that I do understand it I do not accept it. I oppose the concept that a doctor who refuses to perform an abortion discriminates against the mother on the grounds of her sex. The doctor is discriminating between a surgical service which he would perform and in respect of which he has no conscientious objections and one which he does have objections to.

3.2 What if a doctor unreasonably refuses to perform a prostate operation on any man. Such a refusal surely does not involve a discrimination against the male sex. It is against a particular surgical operation. Indeed it might be the case that such a doctor would say that he would similarly refuse to perform that operation if it could be performed on a woman. Likewise a doctor who has a conscientious objection to abortion (i.e. the destruction of a foetus) would consistently refuse to terminate a foetus in a man if it were possible for a man to be pregnant. But it is the nature of the operation which is the basis of objection to its performance, not the nature of the recipient of the operation.

3.3 The matter can be further illustrated by taking the situation of a doctor who refuses to provide blood transfusions under any circumstances. Obviously that doctor, if brought before the Court on the grounds of discriminating against the female sex because he refused to give a blood transfusion to Mary Jones, would say 'I do not refuse to give the blood transfusion because its recipient, Mary Jones, is a woman, I'll give it to no-one, including Bill Jones' . A more realistic example could be a surgical operation for which there are some valid grounds of objection, e.g. face lifts.

3.4 I accordingly consider that the proposition that a doctor discriminates between sexes when he refuses to perform an abortion is untenable. If this were so Mr Bumble's famous dictum 'The law, sir, is an ass' appears credible.

4.1 Accordingly, when I was first requested informally to advise on the Bill I indicated that I did not consider there was a necessity for amendment. Following this representations were made inter alia by the Association with the result there was added to clause 20 the following:
'(1A) Nothing in this section applies to or in respect of the provisions of services, the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to members of one sex.'

4.2 Following this amendment I was asked as to whether it would be necessary or desirable to further amend the Bill. I understood that it would be difficult to obtain further amendments and to press for the same might prejudice the continuance of clause 20 (1A). I accordingly expressed the view that it might not be desirable to 'spoil the ship for a halfpenny of tar'. I adhere to that view.

4.3 On the other hand if there is any concern about the provisions of clause 24 or any other part of the Act in the context of abortion and if the prosecution of further amendments will not prejudice the principle of clause 20 (1A) I see merit in 'a catch all' definition either in section 4 or by adding to clause 20 (1A) after the words 'in this Section' the words 'or elsewhere in this Act'. For reasons previously stated I do not consider there is a real need for any amendment but if it was intended that the Act should not relate in any way to abortion there seems no reason why this cannot be specifically stated (albeit unnecessarily).

—Senator Harradine has had his chance.
—I won't get another chance. What you are saying is wrong. These are the words that are in legislation.
—The honourable senator might let me say something first, then he can reply. I object to his trying to talk me down.
—I am not. I am trying to give you some advice.
—Order! Senator Harradine, Senator Missen has the call.

—I am saying that a person can have a genuinely held conscientious belief. It might be a nazi belief or a racist belief. Some people are genuine in those beliefs; people are conscientious in that sense. Let us take the most extreme case.
—That is nonsense, and you know it. What about the Conciliation and Arbitration Act?
—Senator Harradine is a tiresome man. I wish he would listen to other people at times. This is a democracy in which we live and we are entitled to be heard as well.
—Is it, with the gag?
—If the honourable senator likes I will move for an extension.
—Order! Senator Harradine, you must cease interjecting.

—If one's genuinely held conscientious belief were in the superiority of man, if one believed that men should prevail over women, that men should subjugate women and that women should not go to work-I get letters from people who obviously hold these views and hold them sincerely-this amendment would mean that one would be entitled to ignore the products of this legislation as a whole and do as one wished. To my mind this should be thought about again. Maybe in the other House a limited clause like this which would not be open to that interpretation could be thought of. But this amendment as it stands offers a wholesale right to object to any part of the legislation. Surely it cannot be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will allow Senator Harradine to answer Senator Missen's comments. I will therefore speak very briefly on this matter. I believe that the Government has said that it does not believe that this Bill interferes with religious beliefs. If that is the case, the Government will have no problem in agreeing to Senator Harradine's amendment, because as the situation stands now it affects people with strong religious beliefs. I mention, for instance, the situation of a person wanting to employ someone for his small shop-a corner store. If that person expected certain standards of behaviour from that employee, with whom he would be working in close contact-in this respect there is a difference between a corner store and, say, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-I believe that he must have the option of picking someone who will abide by those standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government may well believe, judging from the interjections we had a few minutes ago from Senator Robertson and others, that some religions are bigoted, but that is not the Government's problem. It is not for the Government to interfere with religious beliefs. There is no place for governments to interfere with religious beliefs in this country. We are very proud of our freedom of religion. If the Government believes that some religions are bigoted, it is not up to the Government to change them. I object very strongly, on behalf of those religions, to the Government's attempt to interfere with some of those religious beliefs. I do not care how the Government feels about this. I do not necessarily agree with some of the religions we have in Australia, but I will never abide a government interfering and saying that these religions are wrong.

Who is the Government, who is the Minister, to interfere? The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) knows who she is. She is arrogantly laughing and saying: 'Yes, I am the Minister'. She may think she is all powerful and, with a Caucus vote behind her and with the Australian Democrats willing to support anything at all that the Government puts up on this issue, she is certainly very powerful. But the Government will rue the day that it interferes with religious beliefs in this country, because that is what it will do if it opposes this amendment put by Senator Harradine. I certainly give it my full support and I hope that Senator Harradine will be able to allay the fears of Senator Missen, whom I believe has incorrectly interpreted the amendment put by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we are working to an unfortunate schedule it is not possible for me to deal with all of these matters. In respect of Senator Missen's speech, I understood that the Opposition was supporting my amendment. I had been given some very great guarantees that the Opposition would support it. Yet Senator Missen opposed it. That is a disgrace. Apparently Senator Missen can pick and choose. Who am I to go to now? Do I go to the Opposition honourable senator who is dealing with the Bill, or do I go to the Whip, and having been told something do I then have to go to every member of the Opposition to find out whether he or she will support it?

SPEECH.PARA: What a specious argument has been put up by Senator Missen. The provisions contained in my amendment are the very conscientious objection provisions that are contained in legislation now. The wording of the amendment was not made up by me. It has a foundation in existing legislation. Senator Missen should know that. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act, for example, is one such piece of legislation. It is not hard for the industrial registrar to determine whether a person is a genuine conscientious objector to joining a union. Which is more important to Senator Missen: To have that conscientious objection provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or to have it put in the Sex Discrimination Bill, which deals with very major moral issues? I would have thought it more important to have it in the Sex Discrimination Bill, which deals with very major and fundamentally important issues of conscience. I am surprised that Senator Missen does not know that, under further sections of the legislation, those on whom the responsibility to question this will include the Human Rights Commission. If the Commission cannot deal with it, it will go to the Federal Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — Briefly, there has been no breaking of agreements. Senator Harradine did have an indication that the Opposition would support amendment No. (13) and, when the vote is recorded, we will. Senator Missen stated a point of view, which as a member of the Liberal Party of Australia he is perfectly entitled to state. We believe that it is one of the strengths of our Party that people are not, each and every one, bound by a Caucus vote. I do not belive it is necessary for me to apologise for Senator Missen. He has stated his point of view, which he is entitled to hold and entitled to express.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government will not accept Senator Harradine's amendment because it undermines the basic purpose of the Sex Discrimination Bill. The Bill says that persons do not have the right to discriminate on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas covered by the Bill. Senator Harradine's amendment, as Senator Missen has pointed out, seeks to reverse that situation and to provide that one does have the right to discriminate if one's conscience tells one that women are inferior, unable to be trusted, or anything else. I use the analogy of the Racial Discrimination Act. Senator Harradine said it would be a dreadful thing if a person could not follow his conscience and discriminate against people in order to protect his business. Everybody knows that when the Racial Discrimination Act was enacted some hotel proprietors said: 'Well, we don 't want to allow Aborigines into our pubs because it might be bad for business'. That is not accepted as proper objection under the Racial Discrimination Act, nor will we accept here that a conscientiously held belief that women are inferior and can be--

—That is nonsense, Senator, and you know it. We are talking about whether people are shacked up together or, whether, for example, they are genuine married couples. That is what you are talking about in regard to the care of children. Now, face the facts.

—Senator Harradine knows that in the case of the residential care of children there is an exemption. There are numerous exemptions in this Bill to provide for when it is important for people to be able to employ married couples for a particular purpose. But in general the Bill is about providing that there shall not be discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy, even if an employer believes that women are inferior or that married women should stay at home and not be entitled to earn income in the paid work force. Under this legislation that conscientiously held belief cannot be used to deny a person's right to employment. Therefore, Senator Harradine's amendment is not acceptable to the Government.

—One of the difficulties with this amendment is that, unfortunately, we do not have a definition. I think that Senator Harradine moved his amendment with a certain intention, and the Opposition supports it with a certain intention, but we are not, to use some of the language used here yesterday, supporting some fruitcake issue; we are not talking about some ratbag idea that somebody can then call a conscientious belief if challenges to the Commission-
—It has to be tested before the Federal Court.

—That is right. I sought some advice on some cases relating to marital status rather than sex discrimination. The legal advice I received was that it was highly unlikely, for example, that the Alderman Pilbeam case would hold up as a conscientious belief. The difficulty is that, because we do not have a definition, we are getting into some conflict as to what the clause is about. The Opposition accepts the high intention of Senator Harradine. I want to make it very clear that we certainly would not support something that we thought would undo the Bill or make a mockery of it. That is why we support it. The Government will take its own legal advice and its own view, but we have that difficulty. I accept Senator Harradine's bona fides. I do not believe he is trying to undo this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The definition contained in this legislation is precisely the same as that contained in other legislation. It will have to be tested in a similar manner to that in which other legislation is tested. Quite frankly, in those circumstances I am glad that Senator Martin showed that Senator Ryan's comments are ludicrous. It was suggested that this was in some way to give nutty people, who may think that males are better than females, some way out of the Bill. It obviously is nonsense. This amendment is to provide a genuine conscientious objection provision for people who should not have to choose between the law and their own consciences on this matter. We should not set up that opportunity if this amendment is lost.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I indicate that I supported the amendment.
—That will be recorded under standing order No. 168.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I indicate that the Opposition wishes to be recorded as having voted for this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 43 to 64.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Page 25, sub-clause 44 (2), line 12, leave out 'before', insert 'either before or after'.
This amendment is self-explanatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government does not accept this amendment. This amendment would substitute the words 'either before or after'-
—If you don't accept it don't argue about it.
—All right, we do not accept it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Page 28, paragraph 52 (1) (b), lines 11 and 12, leave out the paragraph.

This amendment relates to inquiries by the Commissioner where it appears to the Commissioner that a person has done an unlawful act by virtue of Part II. This provision places the Commission in the role of drumming up business and of hearing that business. It is sad that we are closing off debate on this matter. This is a very vital matter which impinges upon the due process principle, but I unfortunately have to move the amendment without further debate.
Amendment negatived.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of clauses 43 to 64 has now expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 65 to 81.

TALK.START.PARA: —This section of the debate will end at 3.26 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate a number of matters. The Opposition has a number of amendments to these clauses, including amendment (13) circulated in the name of the Opposition. I indicate at this stage that we will not move amendment (13). We think Senator Harradine's amendment (16) is a superior amendment. When Senator Harradine moves amendment (16) we will support it. I seek leave to move amendments (11) and (12) together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 33, sub-paragraphs 65 (1) (b) (i) and (ii), lines 7 to 10, leave out the sub-paragraphs.

(12) Page 33, clause 66, lines 14 to 18, leave out the clause, insert the following new clause: Inquiries to be held in private '66. (1) Subject to sub- section (2), an inquiry shall be held in private.
'(2) The Commission may, on the application of the respondent to an inquiry, if it is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, direct that an inquiry, or part of an inquiry, be held in public.'.

The reason I move these amendments together, although one concerns clause 65 (1) and the other concerns section 66, is that they are roughly bracketed in that they both apply to the conduct of an inquiry by the Commission. The first amendment, amendment (11), would have the effect of giving an absolute right to legal counsel when appearing before the Commission. At present clause 65 allows a party to have legal representation only if the Commission gives leave. We think that there should be a right of representation if the person feels that he or she needs legal representation. For a variety of reasons that I will not go into we think that that is a very important right for anyone involved in an inquiry. I am sure the reasons people need legal counsel are manifest on any occasion.
The second amendment relates to inquiries being held in private. The present clause 66 states that inquiries may be held in private. It requires that they be held in public unless:
The Commission may, of its own motion or on the application of a party to the inquiry if it is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, direct that an inquiry . . . be held in private.

We reverse that situation and say that as a general rule inquiries should be held in private, but if the Commission believes it is appropriate they may be held in public. I think that in this sense privacy is very important. The situation in which it is necessary for an inquiry to be public is rather limited , whereas there can be a very important reason for an inquiry being held in private. It may be that if an inquiry is to be held in public certain people would be deterred from making complaints. On the other hand, there may be some mischief done by virtue of the fact that inquiries are likely to be in public. There could be some proceedings which in the end are not justified, but damage may be done, particularly when publicity attends those proceedings.

I would have preferred that the nature of the operation of this Bill be low key and non-controversial. Indeed, I understood that that was the Government's view also. The general holding of inquiries in private would assist this and make them a far less traumatic or intimidatory experience for people, many of whom, to their great surprise, may find a complaint made and pursued against them. As has been exhibited in some of the debate, there is a considerable ignorance on the subject of what is sex discrimination or discrimination on the ground of marital status. That will persist in the minds of many for a considerable time, even though they may be people who do not believe themselves to be particularly bigoted. I may need to say more on our amendment (11). I am afraid that I have two versions of it in my hand. I will leave the matter there but may seek the call again in a moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government does not accept the amendments. It has given great thought to the matters raised by the Opposition but believes that the Bill, as drafted, is more satisfactory than it would be if amended. I point out to Senator Martin that the conciliation proceedings, the first action which follows a complaint being brought under this legislation, will be in private; also that clause 92 provides that particulars of complaints are not to be communicated. So quite a deal of protection is already afforded in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to clause 66, it is the view of the Government that unless circumstances exist which require in camera hearings the Commission's hearings should be in public. The new non-publication clause, clause 67, will provide an added safeguard. Clause 66, as drafted, recognises both the educative value of having a hearing in public and that circumstances exist in which a hearing should be in private. I believe that to be the most satisfactory situation.

With regard to clause 65 and the matter of representation, if counsel assisting is appointed parties have an automatic right of legal representation. In other cases representation is with leave of the Commission. It was not considered necessary to have representation in all cases and a provision such as the Opposition is suggesting may cause problems for a party who cannot afford to have a solicitor present but does not qualify for legal aid. The Commission is not a court and clause 77 makes it clear that the proceedings are to be conducted with as little formality as possible. As drafted, clause 65 is in keeping with this. The clause gives the Commission the option, if the circumstances so warrant, to agree to repre- sentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may reply briefly to the Minister, it may not always be apparent to the Commission why counsel is necessary. People tend to be rather intimidated by legal proceedings, even though they may be informal. They may freeze and not do themselves justice. Frequently, people will use legal counsel, and may strictly need legal counsel, even though they may not be required to in regard to certain provisions, simply because they are literally not capable of handling their cases themselves and of being coherent when being asked questions by people in authority. It really ought to be up to the individual to decide whether or not such support is needed. Frankly, we are thinking particularly of the disadvantaged person. For hearings before the Commission it would not be, I would think, a major undertaking to have someone appear with them. That is all I wish to say concerning our amendment (12).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now obvious that the Government sees the accused as the big, bad employer who has everything at his disposal and the person making the complaint as the poor, disadvantaged woman. That will not always be the case. Surely to heavens the Government can understand that. I propose to bring to the attention of the Minister a situation that is the exact reverse, one in which a rather clever woman has an employer who is a simple soul , who is far from sexually harassing her but who, she decides, she can perhaps have a hold over by making a threat to take action. If such a case reaches the Human Rights Commission and the employer is not capable of representing himself under the Bill as it stands he will not be able to seek legal representation. All of the incriminating evidence can be demanded by the Commission but, as I say, legal representation can be denied the accused. It seems to me incredible that the Government would allow that to happen, would allow someone to be denied legal representation. I cannot understand the Government's thinking; there is no justice in what is proposed. It denies all our normal methods of justice. It is incomprehensible that the Government should say arbitrarily: 'Unless the Human Rights Commission gives permission we will deny these people legal representation. They must be able to stand before the Human Rights Commission and defend themselves. If they are not capable of doing that, bad luck, because we will not allow an automatic right of legal representation.' Such a proposition seems quite incredible.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, if a decision is not taken that for a very special reason proceedings should be held in private they will automatically be held in public and we could have a situation such as already exists, in that some women may hold employers to ransom and say; 'If I do not get that promotion'-or whatever, 'I will take you to the anti-discrimination commission and you will have to put up with all the publicity that goes with that'. Of course, the employer, not wanting the publicity, will perhaps pay up or give the women what she requires. It seems to me again quite incredible that the Minister would not want full protection to allow this to be done in private in the first instance-at least until it reaches the Federal Court of Australia-if it can be done in private, unless the Commissioner believes, for some very special reason, that it should be made public. At least there would be protection for those who are innocent.

We had a situation fairly recently in which a gentleman was called publicly before a board under the provisions of the anti-discrimination legislation in New South Wales. He was hauled before that board and found innocent. The amount of publicity that matter attracted, I believe, was very unjust. The Opposition seeks to amend this provision so that proceedings are held in private at least until a matter reaches the Federal Court. It seems to me that, through intimidation alone, the Minister is attempting to get this legislation through so that women can use intimidation in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status on Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -Senator Walters's deep concern for sexual harassers and discriminating employers is very touching, but I am afraid it leaves me untouched. I must correct a couple of misrepresentations she has made amongst a vast army of misrepresentations which we have had to tolerate from Senator Walters in the course of this debate. Senator Walters talked about the 'accused' and 'offences' . I remind the Committee that we are not dealing with criminal proceedings; we are not dealing with offences. We are dealing with complaints that illegal acts may have been committed. It is very clear from the legislation as it is drafted that if there is a case in which the person complained of-the respondent-feels that he or she needs legal representation and, if the circumstances justify it, that request can be made to the Commission. I see no reason for believing that the Commission will not behave responsibly in this fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is no basis at all for Senator Walters's portrayal of what, apparently , she thinks is a situation of treacherous and vicious women rushing to the Commission in order to destroy the reputation of employers by accusing them of discrimination or sexual harassment. I think that is really a disgraceful caricature of what the situation we are trying to deal with typically is. I just repeat that, having considered very carefully the points raised by the Opposition prior to our reaching this stage of the debate, we believe that the clauses, as drafted, provide both the possiblity of private hearings, where that is justified, and the benefit of public hearings. We believe they provide the possibility of legal representation when circumstances require it but the capacity to proceed informally if circumstances justify that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government was dragged screaming to include the amendments it has already made to this civil liberties area. In one of Senator Ryan's Sex Discrimination Bills-I think it was her second Bill after some amendments were made but really I am not sure which one it was-legal representation could be employed by the Human Rights Commission but the Commission could still deny it to the plaintiff appearing before it. Senator Ryan had legislation in which the situation was that legal representation could be used by the Human Rights Commission but--
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters's remarks are not directed to the clause or to the legislation before us.
—Senator Walters has the call.
—I object very strongly to that point of order taken by the Minister.
—It is not appropriate to object to points of order. Just carry on with your address.
—I would like to talk to the point of order.
—I have ruled on the point of order. There is no point of order. Carry on with your speech.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. As I was saying, the Government has been dragged screaming to this legislation. We had the situation that one of Senator Ryan's Bills provided that a plaintiff was not allowed legal representation unless the Human Rights Commission gave permission. The Human Rights Commission could have legal representation and it could deny legal representation to a plaintiff. We pointed out that that was entirely wrong. Indeed, we fed Senator Ryan the amendments we wanted and she has used some of them. She has not gone far enough. She has adopted some of our amendments. Indeed, she has taken up about 50 or 60 of our amendments that we fed to her. But she has not gone far enough. We need this additional amendment which gives the plaintiff a right to legal representation and, indeed, allows the hearings to be held in private unless otherwise stipulated by the commissioners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on this point. The only reason why I rise is to indicate that previously, when Senator Walters spoke, she suggested that this idea was unprecedented. We have had such situations before where there is discretion by the Commission. One example is the Repatriation Commission. The intent is to try to keep the proceedings at low cost and not to have them in a totally adversary context. I think the two propositions we have in this situation probably turn very much on whether one wants to give the Commissioner that type of discretion. I believe that in these circumstances the Commissioner would be the appropriate person to decide whether the operation should be conducted in private. I am quite sure that, if the circumstances indicated that the protection of individuals was concerned, the Commissioner would, in fact, conduct the proceedings in private.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I think it is a good move, as far as possible, to have the lawyers outside the operation and to have them included only when, indeed, it seems that they would be necessary. The types of circumstances that Senator Walters raised the first time she spoke I think would probably fall within that circumstance and the Commissioner probably would, where it is--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you cannot guarantee that.

—No, one cannot guarantee it. But I am suggesting, Senator, that what is sought, as in the Repatriation Commission, is, in fact, to keep down the costs and to keep the proceedings in a non-adversary situation so that, indeed, many of these things might be able to be settled reasonably and amicably. I do not think we have to say that we are moving the proceedings up to the status of a full court confrontation. The hope might be that the problem can be solved in a less adversary way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very mindful of the fact that we have only eight minutes left of the time to debate a series of amendments. So I will not pick up any of Senator Macklin's arguments. Our arguments are on the record. People can judge our intention and what the effect of the amendments would be. In quiet reflection I say that I am rather anxious to move on a little and to explain one thing that appears on the list of amendments circulated in the name of the Opposition. It is not a numbered amendment. The statement simply appears that clause 78 is to be opposed. That is a fairly bald statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 78 did not seem to us to make much sense. When I turned to the explanatory memorandum to find out why it was included, all I found, as one often does with explanatory memoranda, were the same words as though that explained something when all it did was reiterate what is in the Bill. I would like-not necessarily at this instant because I think it is really more important that Senator Harradine has the opportunity to move his amendment No. (16) and we get a chance to express a view-the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) when she next replies to something to give me an explanation of clause 78. I indicate that, if the explanation is good enough, we will not oppose it; but at this stage we do not see any purpose for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of procedure, I have to put all these clauses as a block. It is not practical to oppose just a single clause. Senator Martin, you will have to move as an amendment, if you wish to do so, that proposed clause 78 be left out.
—I will wait until I hear the explanation.
—That is the only way, in fact, you can achieve that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly correct something that Senator Macklin said. He said that clauses 75 and 76 are references to the Human Rights Commission and not the Commissioner. We do not believe it is appropriate for lawyers to be involved to the extent that some members of the Opposition clearly do. We believe that the provision whereby the Commission can allow, when circumstances justify it, is as Senator Macklin says not a precedent and we believe to be a more acceptable approach. As to Senator Martin's ojections to clause 78, the purpose of clause 78 is to enable the Commission itself to be not put to the task of going through in every inquiry all the exemptions and exceptions in the Sex Discrimination Bill in order to determine whether or not they apply. If a party wishes to raise the application, or possible application, of exemption the Commission will consider it. It may be that the complainant is the first party to raise the possible application of exemption, for example, where the respondent agrees there has been discrimination but says that a particular exemption applies and the complaint alleges misinterpretation of the extent of the exemption. Certainly the clause is aimed at enabling the Commission to deal with matters expeditiously and we believe that is a reasonable clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish it to be recorded that the Opposition voted for the amendments.
—Mr Chairman, I voted for the amendments and I ask that that be placed on the record.
—In accordance with standing order 168 that is approved. Senator Martin, do you wish to move your amendment to clause 78?

—No, Mr Chairman. I will allow debate to proceed. I cannot say that everything Senator Grimes said was wholly intelligible but certainly the clause will not do any harm. At worst it is meaningless and we are not going to the barricades on this one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 81 'Determination of other decision of the Commission' states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: After holding an inquiry, the Commission may- (a) dismiss the complaint the subject of the inquiry; or
(b) find the complaint substantiated and make a determination . . .
The determination may include any one of seven actions. I propose a further clause (1A) and I so move:

(16) Page 37, after sub-clause 81 (1), insert the following sub-clause: ''(1A) (a) Where the Commission dismisses a complaint it may make a declaration that the complainant should pay to the respondent an amount determined by the Commission to reimburse the respondent for costs reasonably incurred in consequence of the complaint.

(b) Where the Commission finds a complaint substantiated, it may make a declaration that the respondent should pay to the complainant (not being the Minister or the Commissioner) an amount determined by the Commission to reimburse the complainant for costs reasonably incurred in substantiating the complaint.''.
This is not an unusual provision to be inserted into legislation. I hope that the amendment will be accepted by the Government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government strongly opposes Senator Harradine's amendment as we are strongly opposed to the idea of an administrative body being given the power to award costs. To include such a provision would encourage more legalistic proceedings thus making them longer and more formal. We are not interested in promoting a lawyer-led recovery with this legislation. The Bill already makes provision in clause 83 for the Human Rights Commission to make recommendations to the Attorney-General concerning reimbursement of expenses incurred by a successful party in an inquiry. We believe that that is a satisfactory situation .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing that is not present-I apologise to the Committee for it-is that I should have included a further provision in sub-clause 81 (2) which states: 'A determination of the Commission under sub-section (1) . . . and sub-section 1(A)'. In those circumstances that is a matter that can be tested in proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia. I acknowledge that. In preparing these amendments I omitted to have a further amendment included. I seek leave to move a further amendment to sub-clause 81 (2 ) to include the words 'or sub-section (1A) after the words 'sub-section (1)'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Include the words 'sub-section 1(A)' after the words 'sub-section (1)'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I hope it will be considered in the House of Representatives that the position with costs here is different. In many commissions and so forth, yes, we do not want lawyers and costs to be incurred; we certainly want to keep costs down. The document read as follows-
M83/11639:SB Senator Brian Harradine,Senator for TasmaniaParliament House, Canberra, A.C.T.
Dear Senator Harradine,

During the Second Reading Debates on the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 you expressed your intention to seek further details of the Government's interpretation of various Articles of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

You will appreciate, as the Bill deals with discrimination in certain specified areas, a number of Articles of the Convention will not be relevant. Article 6 ( exploitation of prostitution), Article 9 (nationality rights), Article 16 ( rights relating to marriage) and Parts V and VI of the Convention, for example, fall outside the scope of this particular legislation. In addition to these a number of aspects of other Articles will also not be relevant.

In assessing the relationship between the Convention and the Bill a further factor to bear in mind is that the Convention deals with two themes: measures to eliminate discrimination by ensuring equality of rights, and measures to prevent discrimination. It is the first of these themes with which Part II of the Sex Discrimination Bill is concerned.

In the light of these matters I enclose a copy of a note my Department has prepared on the interpretation of relevant Articles of the Convention. I understand the Prime Minister wrote to you some time ago in regard to some specific matters of interpretation you raised concerning Articles of the Convention. The attached note is fairly general and if after reading it you see any specific problems you may wish to raise these with me.

During the continuation of your speech on the Sex Discrimination Bill last Friday you also sought an assurance as to the position of pharmacists who did not wish to supply certain drugs, such as abortifacients, to customers. As Senator Ryan indicated at the time, if a pharmacist refused to stock these drugs that pharmacist would not commit an act of discrimination under the legislation. The essence of discrimination in clause 5 of the Bill is less favourable treatment on the ground of the sex of a person. A pharmacist who does not stock particular goods is not in a position to supply them to any person, so the sex, or indeed marital status, of the customer is irrelevant. A further consideration is that the refusal to stock the goods is because of the pharmacist's concern about the nature of the goods, not about the sex of any potential customer.
Yours faithfully,GARETH EVANS
CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF ALL FORMS OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN
Relationship to provisions of the Sex Discrimination Bill
Article 1 Definition of ''discrimination against women''.
Article 2 General obligations to ensure elimination of discrimination against women

The Government is committed to the elimination of discrimination against women and has chosen the Sex Discrimination Bill as an appropriate means of implementing obligations in Article 2. A number of the requirements of this Article can be satisfied by non-legislative means, such as through the conciliation and community education functions vested in the Human Rights Commission under the Sex Discrimination legislation.

Article 3 Article 3 is complementary to Article 2. Whereas Article 2 requires measures to eliminate discrimination, Article 3 requires measures to ensure equality. Article 3 is in general terms and does not oblige State parties to any particular course of action. One of the objectives which the Human Rights Commission has under its own Act and under the Sex Discrimination legislation is to guarantee the human rights and fundamental freedoms of Australians without distinctions such as sex.

Article 4 Article 4 allows States Parties to adopt temporary special measures to accelerate the achievement of equality between men and women: however these measures must be discontinued when their objectives have been achieved. Article 4.2 allows State Parties to adopt measures aimed at protecting maternity. These matters are reflected in the exemptions provided in the Sex Discrimination Bill.
Article 5 Article 5 requires appropriate measures-

(a) to modify social and cultural patterns of conduct of men and women, with a view to achieving elimination of prejudices and customary and all other practices which are based on the idea of the inferiority or the superiority of either of the sexes or on stereotyped roles for men and women.

This obligation is concerned with measures to eliminate prejudices and practices based on inferiority or superiority of either sex or on stereotyped roles of men and women. Stereotyping occurs where a particular role which is quite capable of being performed by either sex, is regarded as the preserve of one sex only, that is, without reference to the capabilities of individual members of that sex. The Sex Discrimination Bill is concerned with equality of opportunity. Neither the Convention nor the Bill requires that a man or woman is to be compelled to choose any particular role or to avail themselves of this equality of opportunity.

(b) to ensure family education includes a proper understanding of maternity as a social function and the recognition of the common responsibility of men and women in the upbringing and development of their children, it being understood that the interest of the children is the primordial consideration in all cases.

This obligation is not concerned with the actions of individuals and how they instruct their families. The Government interprets this obligation consistently with Article 23 of the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights which recognizes that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection. Part II of the Sex Discrimination Bill is not inconsistent with the principle in Article 23.
Articles 7 and 8 These Articles are concerned with equal participation in public and political life and are self-explanatory.

Article 10 Article 10 contains a number of specific requirements aimed at equality of opportunity and access to education and the elimination of discrimination. This will enable men and women to compete on the basis of skills and merit without regard to their sex. Similarly the Sex Discrimination Bill contains provisions aimed at ensuring equality of access to education and training. The Article does not require the abolition of single-sex schools but requires opportunities to be made available for equivalent standards of education, equivalent courses of study and equal access to higher education. The Article is also concerned with the quality of access to specific educational information on matters of health but not with the content of that information.

Article 11 Article 11 contains a number of specific requirements aimed at equality of rights in employment and employment-related areas. Sub-Article 11.1 is concerned with equal enjoyment of the rights listed therein and does not create separate rights for women. In this regard two matters should be noted: first, the reservation lodged on ratification in regard to employment of women in the Defence Force in combat and combat-related duties and secondly, the recognition in sub-Article 11.3 of the existence of certain ''protective legislation'' which may be applicable to matters listed in the Article.
The Sex Discrimination Bill contains provisions aimed at the elimination of discrimination in matters relating to work.

Sub-Article 11.2 provides that certain measures should be taken in order to prevent discrimination against women on the ground of marriage or maternity and to ensure their effective right to work. Regard should also be had to the reservation lodged on ratification in respect of paid maternity leave. Paragraph 11.2 (a), prohibition of dismissal on the ground of pregnancy or maternity leave and discrimination in dismissals on the basis of marital status, is the only part of the sub-Article of direct relevance to the Sex Discrimination Bill.

Article 12 Sub-Article 12.1 deals with equality of access to health care services. These are matters falling within the prohibition in the Sex Discrimination Bill on discrimination in the provision of services and facilities. The sub-Article is concerned with the provision of access to services and does not impose an obligation to provide services that are not already available.

Article 13 Article 13 is concerned with equality in economic and social life. In this regard the Sex Discrimination Bill covers discrimination in regard to the provision of services, Article 13 (b) (the right to bank loans, mortgages and other forms of financial credit), and in regard to clubs, Article 13 (c) (the right to participate in recreational activities, sports and all aspects of cultural life). In regard to Article 13 (c), this obligation is to give women the same freedom of choice as regards what sporting and recreational activities they may wish to pursue as men. It does not require that all such sporting activities be mixed.

Article 14 Article 14 is concerned with the special problems of rural women. The rights enumerated in sub-Article 14 (2) are interpreted as being concerned with the equality of rural women and rural men.

Article 15 Article 15 is concerned with the question of equality of men and women before the law. This question is of indirect relevance to the Sex Discrimination Bill in that men and women are treated equally in all stages of procedure before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and the Commission. Further , the Australian legal system does not treat women as second class citizens or give them a lesser right than men in relation to the capacity to maintain legal proceedings or enter into contractual or other legal relationships.

STATEMENT ON THE THIRD READING OF THE SEX DISCRIMINATION BILL
1. We, the undersigned, have determined to vote in support of the third reading of this Bill.
2. It has not been an easy decision and has been taken with a number of reservations. Nevertheless, we have reached our decision upon the following factors.

(a) The Opposition stands firmly against discrimination in any form, including discrimination on the basis of sex, marital status or pregnancy. Our stand on this Bill has never been directed to the objectives of the Bill but against the means adopted by the Government to attain those objectives.

(b) Whilst the original Bill was an ill-considered and poorly drafted document, the Bill, in its present form, is workable and incorporates more than 53 changes ; those amendments in general having been made by the Government in response to representations by the Opposition and other interested individuals and organisations. The point is that the Government has come a long way down the road to accommodate legitimate objections to its original proposal.

(c) The freedom of religious schools will now be preserved. The Bill cannot now be used to force unwilling persons to participate in abortion procedures. The initial provisions infringing civil liberties have been removed.

(d) The debate generated by the Bill has indicated a number of areas of public concern as to the effect its implementation will have upon the structure of our society. Accordingly, it is pleasing to note that the Bill will not provide for affirmative action. Neither will the more unsatisfactory provisions of the UN Convention, for example the provision calling for supervision by a UN Committee, be implemented.
3. While we are particularly concerned about the use of the external affairs power much of the Bill is based on other legitimate heads of Commonwealth power.

4. There should be no doubt that both Government and the Opposition regards this Bill as significant. In the light of that significance it may well be appropriate for a Parliamentary Committee to review its operation in a few years to ensure that the positive results hoped for are achieved and to see if further amendments are required to redirect the legislation to achieve those ends.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Treasurer consider the introduction of a means-tested income tax rebate for families and single parents on a percentage of home and accommodation rentals to offset the discrimination between owner-occupiers and the growing number of rental tenants in areas of housing assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I announced in my May economic statement a significant increase in assistance for public housing. Assistance under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement is being increased in 1983-84 to $500m-an increase of $167m, or 50 per cent on the $333m provided in 1982-83.

through supplementary rental assistance to eligible pensioners-estimated cost $ 164m in 1982-83; and

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the rate of growth in the money supply during March and April 1983 when expressed as an annual rate.
(2) Did interest rates fall over the same period.
(3) Did the Treasurer announce a $1.5 billion bond tender on 19 May 1983; if so , what will be the effect on the money supply.
(4) What effect did this announcement have on interest rates.
(5) Do the answers to the previous questions indicate that a tight monetary policy is associated with high interest rates and depressed economic activity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The growth rate of M3 expressed on a twelve-months-to basis decreased from 12.4 per cent in March to 11.7 per cent in April 1983.

(2) Most short term interest rates decreased appreciably during the March-April period. For example, the 90-day bank accepted/endorsed commercial bill rate fell from 17.0 per cent at end-February to 12.65 per cent at end-April. Medium and long term secondary market Treasury Bond rates also fell during this period. For example, secondary market yields on five year Treasury bonds fell about three- quarters of a percentage point between end-February and end-April.

(3) The Treasurer did announce a $1,500m bond tender on 19 May 1983. The settlement dates for the tender were 30 May to 24 June, so that its impact on the money supply would have been reflected in the June and later figures. The growth rate of M3 was 11.2 per cent over the 12 months to May 1983 but 12.5 per cent over the 12 months to June 1983. This outcome was influenced by several factors, including foreign exchange inflows, the Budget surplus, and the transactions of the Reserve Bank and private banks, as well as by Government financing transactions. Nevertheless, the tender announced on 19 May would have contributed to a lower monetary growth in June than if the tender had been smaller.

(4) Immediately following the tender announcement on 19 May, most short term rates and secondary market Treasury bond yields rose, continuing a trend evident over the previous week. A decline in hedged overseas borrowing costs and substantial foreign exchange inflows in subsequent days resulted in short term rates declining to levels only slightly above their pre-tender announcement levels by the start of the settlement period on 30 May. In contrast, secondary market bond yields at the beginning of the settlement period remained at the higher post-announcement levels, although this can by no means be attributed solely to the tender.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Treasurer say in his economic statement of 19 May 1983 that monetary growth at 12 per cent 'is not consistent with this Government's objectives'.
(2) What was the rate of growth in M1 and M3 in the year to March 1983 and did the rate of growth in M3 exceed that of M1.

(3) Does M3 include bank deposits on which market rates of interest are paid and does this not mean that banks can offer high interest rates when liquidity is tight so as to offset Government's attempt to control the money supply with open market operations.
(4) Is M1 a better measure of the tightness of liquidity.
(5) What was the real rate of growth in M1 in the year to March 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The growth rates of M1 and M3 in the twelve months to March 1983 were 1.8 per cent and 12.4 per cent respectively.

(3) The volume of money measure M3 includes trading bank fixed deposits and certificates of deposit as well as savings bank investment accounts and statement savings accounts on which market or near-market interest rates are paid. Open market operations involving the sale of additional Commonwealth Government securities to the non-bank sector by the Reserve Bank have the effect of reducing the overall volume of funds available to the banking system as deposits.

One response of the banks to such operations could be an increase in their deposit rates designed to limit their loss of deposits. However, such action by itself is unlikely to offset fully the lower deposit growth resulting from the open market operations. This is because the increase in bank deposit rates will need to be reflected in bank lending rates and, as these increase, it is reasonable to expect that there will be an increasing reluctance by borrowers from banks to pay the higher interest rates. Faced with the consequent fall-off in demand for borrowings, the banks' ability to offer higher interest rates will be necessarily inhibited and, hence, so will be the banks' ability to offset fully the open market operations.

(4) No single measure is adequate on its own for measuring the liquidity of the financial system. An accurate assessment of monetary and liquidity conditions can only be reached after considering a wide range of financial indicators. For example, the M1 aggregate needs to be interpreted with particular caution at present since the relatively high nominal interest rates on most interest bearing bank deposits and other financial assets have resulted in individuals economising on balances held in cheque accounts. As these cheque accounts are included in M1, this aggregate has therefore grown more slowly recently than most other financial aggregates and accordingly does not reflect the easier liquidity conditions more generally.

All measures of monetary and liquidity conditions-including M3-are subject to a variety of structural and cyclical influences that must be taken into account in assessing their effectiveness in portraying monetary conditions. The choice of one monetary aggregate over another as a better measure of monetary conditions must ultimately reflect a judgment as to the relative disadvantages and advantages of each aggregate. In this regard, M3 appears to be more representative of general monetary conditions, less susceptible to short-term volatility and has a greater level of community understanding than M1. It is considered a more appropriate summary measure of monetary conditions.

(5) Real growth rates of monetary and other aggregates are dependent on the choice of the price deflator used in the calculation. Based on movements in the Consumer Price Index, the real movement of M1 in the twelve months to March 1983 was minus 8.7 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are small businessmen linked to a $1,200 tax deduction for contributions they make to superannuation funds, payments from which will be subject to the new 'super tax'.

(2) How can employees operating contributory superannuation schemes, obtain tax benefits which, together with the $1,200 rebate theoretically obtainable by employees for their contributions, amount to far higher (perhaps three or four times more) tax subsidies than are available to the self-employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The income tax law allows a self-employed person or an employee without employer-sponsored superannuation support an income tax deduction for his or her contributions to a qualifying superannuation fund up to an annual limit of $1, 200. Benefits from such a superannuation fund, to the extent to which they are referable on a time basis to membership of the fund after 30 June 1983, will be subject to the new taxing arrangements.

(2) The honourable senator seems to be asking why income tax deductions available for contributions to a supperannuation fund by an employer for the benefit of an employee can be much higher than the deduction for such contributions available to an employee who has to make his or her own superannuation arrangements. The former contributions are, of course, deductible to the employer as part of the overall remuneration payable in respect of the employment of the employee, are part of the costs of derivation of the employer' s income and are funded in accordance with guidelines which reflect the employer -employee relationship. The latter contributions have no direct relationship to the derivation of the taxpayer's income and the deduction of up to $1,200 represents a concession under the income tax law which would not otherwise be available to assist unsupported employees and self-employed persons to provide for retirement. As the honourable senator would know, the level of concessions of this nature under the income tax law are subject to budgetary considerations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1983:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Treasurer consider authorising the Foreign Investment Review Board to release full details of any purchases of Australian rural land by foreign interests, including the full identification of the purchaser(s), the amount tendered for the property, the location of the property, the area of the property, details of prior advertising on the Australian market and the purpose to which the property will be put; if not, why not.
