QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is the new tax on cosmetics containing sunscreen agents based on the marketing technique of a product rather than the effectiveness of that product to protect the skin from harmful ultra-violet rays.

(2) Are there any products that contain an effective level of sunscreen agents, with the exception of night preparations which will attract this new tax; if not , would it not be more effective to amend the present legislation to exempt night preparations; if so, why has the Government decided to tax these products when they afford the wearer protection from ultra-violet rays.

(3) Why is the Government not encouraging the manufacturers of cosmetics worn during the day to include in their products an effective level of sun screening agents rather than discouraging them from this practice by way of a tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no new tax on cosmetics containing sunscreen agents. Cosmetics have been taxable for many years. However, prior to the August 1983 Budget various cosmetics had gained exemption under a provision conferring exemption on sunscreen preparations by having included in the ingredients of the cosmetics a sunscreen agent. Notwithstanding the inclusion of the sunscreen agent the products remain essentially cosmetics. The effect of the Budget amendment made to the exemption provision (item 38A in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act) is to exclude cosmetics with sunscreen agents from exemption and to tax them at the same rate as other cosmetics. The exemption for sunscreen preparations has, ever since it was introduced, been dependent on the effectiveness of the preparations in screening out solar ultra- violet rays. The exemption has also been dependent on the manner in which the product is put up for sale.
Sunscreen preparations which are not essentially cosmetics but which are effective and are put up for sale for the purpose of screening out solar ultra- violet rays remain exempt from sales tax.

(2) Cosmetics, cosmetic preparations and goods in the nature of cosmetic preparations are now excluded from exemption and are taxed even though they might have a sunscreen agent in them which effectively screens out solar ultra- violet rays. It is not proposed to amend the law to exempt night preparations. The Government has excluded the cosmetics, et cetera. with sunscreen agents for exemption because they are essentially cosmetics and should bear the same rate of sales tax as other cosmetics.

(3) The Government has never intended to exempt cosmetics. It is concerned that cosmetics which include sunscreen agents, even those with effective sunscreen agents, should not gain a competitive advantage over other cosmetics because of sales tax. The Government continues to encourage the use of sunscreen preparations as such by exempting those which effectively screen out solar ultra -violet rays.

(3) What fees and commissions, if any, are paid to foreign banks and other financial institutions for holding Australia's foreign exchange reserves.
(4) Has an investigation been conducted into the feasibility of holding Australia's foreign exchange reserves in overseas branches of Australian banks; if so, what are details.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1983 (Hansard, page 525), Senator Jessop asked the Minister for Social Security a question without notice concerning the Government 's new taxation arrangements for lump sum superannuation and kindred benefits. In responding to him Senator Grimes indicated, inter alia, that he would pass the question on to the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance for any additional comment which they might like to make.

QUESTION.PARA: The Treasurer has now provided the following response in answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is true that most lump sums received by individuals are relatively small and such lump sums would only purchase modest annuities. However, the average size of lump sums received by genuine retirees, which is the group for which the annuity option is relevant, would be significantly higher than the figures quoted by Senator Jessop which related to lump sums received both prior to and at genuine retirement from the workforce.

Of course, the Government's new tax arrangements for lump sums will not in any way compel lump sum recipients to take annuities on retirement nor will they provide any special tax inducements to take this course of action. Under the new measures, on retirement, a lump sum recipient will have two choices. First, he can take his lump sum and pay tax on it (generally at 15 per cent after the transitional provisions have worked their way through). Alternatively he can roll the lump sum over into a pension or annuity in which case tax on the lump sum will be deferred by the individual until received as part of his regular stream of pension or annuity payments at which time it will (after the transitional provisions no longer operate) generally be taxed according to the rates applying under the ordinary income tax rate scale. The new arrangements have been designed with the aim of making the effective tax burdens approximately equivalent under either alternative, so that those persons who choose not to convert their lump sum into a pension or annuity will not be disadvantaged.

The answer to the first part of the question was given on 21 September 1983 ( Hansard, page 855). The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question:

The Budget forecast of an increase in the consumer price index, in 1983-84 of about 7 1/2 per cent included an estimate of the effect of increases in State taxes and public authority charges announced prior to the Budget (mainly in Western Australia and South Australia). ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Public Benevolent Institutions: Sales Tax Exemptions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1983 (Hansard, page 963), Senator Zakharov asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: My question, which I address to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the granting of sales tax exemptions for goods bought for use by public benevolent institutions. The Commissioner of Taxation has ruled, on the basis of High Court decisions, that an organisation is not a public benevolent institution unless it has as its dominant objective, both in constituting documents and in practice, the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness. His interpretation is that these criteria rule out counselling and referral centres such as citizens advice bureaux. Since such centres do, in fact, relieve suffering, distress and helplessness and assist people to obtain relief from poverty, destitution and sickness, it would seem the ruling is based on an outmoded view that 'relief' means the direct provision of material relief. . . . My question is:
'Will the Government take action to remove this anomaly which denies sales tax exemption for essential equipment for vital community services?'
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that exemption from sales tax for purchases by non-profit community organisations, including citizens advice bureaux, depends on whether the organisations qualify as public benevolent institutions.

The Commissioner confirmed that High Court decisions have established that an organisation is not a public benevolent institution unless it has as its dominant objective, both in its constituting documents and in practice, the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune or helplessness. It is a question of fact in each case whether a particular organisation qualifies as a public benevolent institution.

The Commissioner does not hold the view that counselling and the giving of advice can never be activities of a benevolent nature in the sense established by the High Court. There are, however, many organisations which provide worthwhile community and welfare services. Such organisations may provide to members of the public generally welfare and community services such as counselling, referral and educational services in problems in certain areas, for example marriage, law, health and employment. These services certainly meet a community and social need and, indeed, in many instances are financed by Government grants and have Government support in other ways. Nevertheless, their activities are not necessarily directed to the relief of persons suffering poverty, misfortune, distress, etc.

An amendment to the law would be required to extend sales tax concessions to counselling and referral centres, such as citizens advice bureaux. Such a question would need to be examined in the context of the competing claims made by many other kinds of non-profit community organisations whose activities are also worthy, but which are not at present eligible for exemption.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2759) Senator Coates asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) a question without notice about a statement by the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, Mr Leslie, concerning the numbers of public servants and people from this Parliament using Qantas for their travel. Senator Button responded to the question but undertook to obtain from the relevant Minister a comment on the figures quoted by Mr Leslie for usage of Qantas by public servants and parliamentarians.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) as the responsible Minister has provided the following response:

The Government does not maintain statistics on the use of Qantas by members of Parliament or public servants. The Government has no reason to doubt the accuracy of the statistics quoted by the Chairman of Qantas.

In elaboration of the comments made by Senator Button in his preliminary response to Senator Coates' question I wish to record the fact that Finance Directions require Qantas services to be used on all occasions where available flights meet requirements for official travel at Commonwealth expense by Commonwealth public servants travelling overseas. The Directions also require that where suitable flights are not available, preference be given to services of airlines with which Qantas has revenue pooling arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2249) Senator Bjelke- Petersen asked me the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: My question is to the Attorney-General. I refer him to a report in the Australian newspaper last week in which it was stated that a Mr Peter Niarros, a boilermaker at Mount Newman, was receiving bomb threats and was to be dismissed following his refusal to pay $20 to a union strike fund. In view of this blatant violation of Mr Niarros's human rights, will the Attorney refer his case urgently to the Human Rights Commission for immediate investigation and action? In view of the Attorney's much flaunted belief in human rights, will he give an unequivocal assurance that the human rights legislation will extend to those unions which have shown on many occasions that they will not hesitate to use standover tactics, including bomb threats and abusive phone calls, to violate the human rights and liberties of those people in our community who will not bow to their demands?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

With regard to the first part of the honourable senator's question, I should mention that the complaint handling function of the Human Rights Commission relates to acts and practices engaged in by or on behalf of the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority, or in a Territory, or under Commonwealth or Territory law. There is, I think, a question whether the action taken against Mr Niarros referred to by the honourable senator is an act or practice of that kind. However, if it appears to Mr Niarros that the matter may be within the Commission's functions, his appropriate course would be to take up the matter with the Commission by lodging a complaint.

As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, as I indicated in my earlier answer, the content of the proposed Bill of Rights will be made public when the Bill is introduced early in the autumn session.
